FY 19-20.actionsImplemented5: A meeting was had that included ASRC, DAES, NYS Mesonet and School of Education to discuss education activities with school teachers.
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults1:
(i)Presented xCITE at an ASRC colloquay to help promote the laboratory (M1)

(ii)Working with ASRC and COE, developed a number of proposals that exploit the xCITE laboratory. Secured more than $3.2M in new grant money for UAlbany including $2.4M as participants in the $20M NSF-supported AI Institute. (M3)

(iii)Worked with UAlbany, Media and Marketing on promotional stories (M4), see:

UAlbany story: https://www.albany.edu/news-center/news/look-inside-xcite-laboratory

UAlbany video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E7JbaBhsGHY

STEM 13 segment: https://wnyt.com/education-stem/xcite-lab-ualbany/5637633/

Times Union (AI Institute): https://www.timesunion.com/news/article/UAlbany-researchers-harnessing-Artificial-15541157.php

WNYT (AI Institute): https://wnyt.com/albany-ny-education-stem/artificial-intelligence-winter-weather-forecasting-ualbany-university-at-albany/5843373/?cat=10114

(iv)Celebrated the xCITE laboratory through a table demonstration at three notable events: the NYSTAR Innovation Summit (October 2019), the AMS annual meeting in Boston (Jan 2020) and at the SUNY Showcase at Status of the University, Albany (Jan 2020). (M4)

(v)Deployment of NYS Mesonet App on both Apple (548 users) and Android (92 users) platforms in January 2020 (See: https://www.albany.edu/news/93275.php) (M4)
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults2:
New funding included Sara Lance’s NSF Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award from NSF ($684K) to study the chemistry taking place in clouds around Whiteface Mountain. Also Jim Schwab’s NYSERDA award ($399K) to support “Mobile Laboratory Measurements of Methane, Ethane, and Co-pollutants from Landfills, Oil and Gas Systems and Other Sources in New York State” is recommended for funding. Also, Jim Schwab received a new Sub-award from the University of Rochester to study “Long-Term Monitoring of Methane within NYS Phase II: Assessing Trends in Sources and Characterizing Hot Spots”, ($22,044)(M1)

(i)Established plans to celebrate the 50th Anniversary of Whiteface including contributions to the Falconer public seminar series in summer, a white paper on the vision for the next decades, a banquet (to be held in Albany; will invite DEC Commissioner to speak) and an invitation to host a visit to Whiteface for President Rodriguez and members of his executive council. (M2)

(ii)The following papers were published (M2): 

Zhang, J., S. Lance, J.M. Freedman, Y. Sun, B.A. Crandall, X. Wei, J. J. Schwab, “Detailed measurements of submicron particles from and Independence Day fireworks event in Albany, NY using HR-ToF-AMS”, ACS Earth Space Chem., DOI:10.1021/acsearthspacechem.9b00046.

Zhang, J. S. Lance, R. Brandt, J. Marto, M. Ninneman, and J. J. Schwab, “Observed below-cloud and cloud interstitial aerosol chemical and physical properties at Whiteface Mountain, New York during August 2017”, ACS Earth Space Chem., DOI:10.1021/acsearthspacechem.9b00117

Zhang, J., M. Ninneman, E. Joseph, M.J. Schwab, B. Shrestha, and J.J. Schwab (2020), “Mobile laboratory measurements of high surface ozone levels and spatial heterogeneity during LISTOS 2018: Evidence for sea-breeze influence”, J. Geophys. Res., https://doi.org/10.1029/2019JD031961

Zhou, C., H. Zhou, T.M. Holsen, P.K. Hopke, E.S. Edgerton, and J. J. Schwab, “Ambient ammonia concentrations across New York State”, J. Geophys. Res.: Atmospheres, 124, https://doi.org/10.1029.2019JD030380.

Luo, G., F. Yu, and J.J. Schwab, “Revised treatment of wet scavenging processes dramatically improves GEOS-Chem 12.0.0. simulations of nitric acid, nitrate, and ammonium over the United States”, Geoscientific Model Development, 12, 3439-3447, https://doi.org/10.5194/gmd-12-3439-2019.

Two other notable papers are in press:
Zhang, J., S. Lance, X. Wang, J. Wang and J.J. Schwab, Estimation of aerosol liquid water from optical scattering instruments using ambient and dried sample streams, Atmos. Environ., Accepted July 2020.

Lance, S., J. Zhang, J.J. Schwab, P. Casson, R.E. Brandt, D.R. Fitzjarrald, M.J. Schwab, J. Sicker, C.-H. Lu, S.-P. Chen, J. Yun, J.M. Freedman, B. Shrestha, Q. Min, M. Beauharnois, B. Crandall, E. Joseph, M.J. Brewer, J.R. Minder, D. Orlowski, A. Christiansen, A.G. Carlton, M.C. Barth, Overview of the Cloud Processing of Organics within Clouds (CPOC) Pilot Study at Whiteface Mountain, NY, Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., Accepted July 2020.

(iii)The ASRC Whiteface Mountain Field Station has been working to improve the infrastructure at the summit observatory over the past year. We started out 2020 with plans for upgrades to the observatory including structural repairs as well as electrical upgrades and a roof replacement project. These plans were to coincide with the 50th anniversary of the observatory and also to predicate deployment of several new instruments by Dr. Sara Lance. Several meetings were held with Facilities Management staff as well as the design team from CSARCH. The work was put out to bid in April 2020. Only one bid was received and was determined to be too high. Due to financial constraints related to the COVID-19 pandemic it was decided that the scope of the project should be reduced and put back out to bid. We decided to focus on the most urgent need which is the roof replacement. However even with the reduced scope of work we were informed that there were not funds available to move forward this year. The current plan is to have staff from the UALBANY roofing shop come up on Wednesday 9/16/2020 to attempt to refasten the existing roof to get us through the winter. We are hopeful that a more permanent fix will be forthcoming in the near future. (M3)

(iv)The EIP search was initiated. (M4)
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults3:
(i)New funding included Richard Perez’s continued support from Clean Power Research ($300K) and Natural Resource Canada ($75K). (M2)

(ii)Richard Perez published extensively on the perfect forecast/firm power – 3 joint peer-review articles, 2 invited conference presentations and several webinars (M3)

(iii)The Firm Power forecast is one of the research foci for the Clean Power Research Project (see above). (M3)

(iv)Richard spearheaded and is now leading a new International Energy Agency Task on Firm Power Generation: IEA PVPS Task 16 3.5. (M3)

(v)Jeff Freedman led a DOE Offshore Wind proposal: leading a team with 5 universities, 4 private sector partners on a $14.5 million (with cost-share) proposal to conduct an observational and modeling campaign on the offshore wind resource along the mid-Atlantic and northeast coastal waters. (M4)

(vi)Jeff Freedman, Co-chaired the AMS 11th Conference on Weather, Climate, and the New Energy Economy (January 2020) and was Invited to lead a panel on climate and extreme weather at the American Wind Energy Association Wind Resource Assessment conference (end of September 2020).

(vii)Dr.'s Richard Perez and Jeff Freedman (together with Jerry Brotzge and Chris Thorncroft)  created a whitepaper that provides a vision for how weather information, including the NYS Mesonet, will help NY State achieve its 100% renewables goal by 2040. Efforts are ongoing to promote this with the State and the public. Interviews were also given on “Capitol Tonight” on Spectrum News and for the “Capital Pressroom”, WCNY. (M5)

(viii) Publications include (M5):

Perez R. et al., (2020) From Firm Solar Power Forecasts to Firm Solar Power Generation an Effective Path to Ultra-High renewable Penetration a New York Case Study. Energies 2020, 13, 4489.

Pierro M., R. Perez, M. Perez, D. Moser, M. Giacomo and C. Cornaro, (2020) Italian protocol for massive solar integration: imbalance mitigation strategies. Renewable Energy journal, 153, pp 725-739

Pierro, M., Moser, D., Perez, R., Cornaro, C. The Value of PV Power Forecast and the Paradox of the “Single Pricing” Scheme: The Italian case Study, Energies 2020, 12, 3045
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults4:
(i)Performed visual quality screening of New York State Mesonet (NYSM) soil moisture observational records at 119 stations. Identified data quality issues related to frozen soil conditions, service disruptions, as well as site- and soil moisture retrieval-specific soil type disparities. These issues were reported to the NYSM, which addressed the frozen soil and disruption effects in a March 2020 reprocessed release of the full NYSM soil moisture and temperature record (November 2015–December 2019). Soil type corrections will be left to the discretion of the end-user. (M1)

(ii)Demonstrated added-value of NASA Soil Moisture Active Passive satellite-derived soil moisture data assimilation in a short-term weather forecast context in conditionally-accepted article in Monthly Weather Review (M1):

Ferguson, C.R., S. Agrawal, M. Beauharnois, G. Xia, D.A. Burrows and L. Bosart (2020), Satellite soil moisture assimilation for improved forecasts of Great Plains low-level jet ramp events, Mon. Wea. Rev..

(iii)Development of a mesonet--National Water Model-satellite soil moisture data fusion approach is ongoing in collaboration with Princeton University and Duke University collaborators. Once proven, the approach will be integrated in the form of an observational operator in the U.S. multi-agency Joint Effort for Data Assimilation Integration (JEDI) system.  (M1)

(iv)A proposal was submitted to NASA to develop dynamic vegetation root-groundwater interactions within the National Water Model.  (M1)

(v)A proposal to NASA to extend the SMAP soil moisture data assimilation work was not selected for funding but will be resubmitted in some form. (M1)

(vi)Efforts remain ongoing to develop collaborations with the Canal Corporation, USGS and the NE River Forecasting Center. USGS is currently incorporating one NYS Mesonet station into its ice-jamming monitoring efforts. (M2)

(vii) A proposal is currently planned for submission in the coming year that is based on SAFER. Partners currently include ASRC, DAES, CEHC and Penn State. (M3)
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults5:
(i)June Wang (NYS Mesonet) has developed relationships with key people in SOE and in some local schools and has led a proposal on “Backyard Weather Science: A Data Intensive online Environment for next generation STEM teaching and learning”. (M1)

(ii)Media and marketing are working on a story that highlights a summer interaction between the NYS Mesonet (June Wang) and a local school teacher. (M2)
FY 19-20.changes1: There has been a delay in establishing the campus-wide weather AI/ML group due to bandwidth, but we will endeavor to achieve this in the coming year, buoyed by the new AI institute.
FY 19-20.changes2: Due to the pandemic, the WFM Field Station 50th Anniversary celebrations were postponed and will now hopefully take place in late summer 2021.
FY 19-20.changes3: The EIP hire was delayed due to University budget issues
FY 19-20.changes4: The proposal based on SAFER was delayed due to bandwidth. Efforts are ongoing to create a new proposal in the next 6 months.
FY 19-20.changes5: This effort requires funding and so more efforts will be made to achieve this.  Consideration will be given to establishing a committee led by June Wang.
FY 19-20.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch:
There are several big opportunities for significant growth at ASRC:

(i)Weather-AI – Need to initiate the Winter Weather project in the AI Institute and leverage this for more research activity beyond that which is funded by NSF.

(ii)Renewable Energy – This remains a topic that we need to maintain strength in and grow.

(iii)Planetary Boundary Layer and Air Quality  - There is a big opportunity to grow this area and to establish collaborations with Oklahoma University and CUNY.
FY 19-20.resourceNeeds:
(i) Resources to hire the two EIP positions (replacing retired faculty)
(ii) Resources to maintain COE
(iii) Resources to run the NYS Mesonet
FY 19-20.strategicSuggestions:
(i) Working with Federal lobbyist towards establishing Federal support for Boundary layer/Profiler research through appropriations.

(ii) Working with Federal lobbyist and Oklahoma University to establish partnership with respect to their NOAA CI re-bid in 2021.

(iii) Continue to collaborate with CEHC together with DAES on research and research proposals.

(iv) Continue to strengthen research ties with Wadsworth and School of Public Health.
FY 19-20.otherthoughts: If we want to take advantage of the huge opportunities that exist in Atmospheric Sciences research we should endeavor to fill the two EIP positions.

FY 20-21.mission: The Atmospheric Sciences Research Center (ASRC), of the State University of New York at Albany, was established on February 16, 1961 by the Board of Trustees of the State University of New York, as a SUNY system-wide resource for developing and administering programs in basic and applied sciences related to the atmospheric environment. ASRC's world-class researchers study the physical and chemical processes of the atmosphere, land, and water systems, and apply that knowledge to explore the interaction of chemical, physical, geological and biological processes that impact our environment. Through technology transfer and collaboration with state, federal and industrial partners, ASRC enhances New York State's scientific capacity and infrastructure, while advancing the quality of life and economic wellbeing of its citizens.
FY 20-21.vision: The vision for the center in the coming year is to maintain our traditional strengths but also to seek out and strengthen strategic collaborations in key research areas including two areas that will get renewed focus this year: (i) Boundary Layer and Air Quality and (ii) Aerosol-Cloud-Precipitation-Weather-Climate Interactions.
FY 20-21.annualBudget: ASRC needs additional time to input this information!
FY 20-21.goal1:
Strengthen and promote Weather-AI and Data Analytics capabilities at ASRC building on the recently established xCITE laboratory:
(1) Promote usage of the xCITE laboratory in ASRC, DAES and the University campus in the area of Artificial intelligence and Machine Learning. Measurable: number of users. (2) Initiate a campus Weather AI/ML group to exchange ideas, promote research and coordinate research proposals. Measurable: number of members in the group (3) Secure additional external funding in the Weather-AI and Data analytics domain. Measurable: booked research support (4) Increase exposure of the xCITE facility and related activities through publications, conference/workshop demonstrations; website; logos, media and marketing etc: Measurable: Numbers of papers, presentations, public awareness.
FY 20-21.goal2: Expand and Promote Atmospheric Chemistry and Air Quality Research and Outreach activities at ASRC’s facility at Whiteface Mountain (WFM): (1) Maintain and extend external research funding for field research at WFM that expands upon and complements the long term measurements obtained at the site which began nearly 50 years ago. Measurable: booked research support (2) Elevate the profile of research conducted at WFM by publishing findings from projects in peer reviewed journals, presenting findings at national and international conferences, and participating in outreach activities including celebration of 50th Anniversary in 2020. Measurable: Numbers of papers, presentations and public awareness (3) Maintain and develop research infrastructure at WFM to enhance research capabilities and collaboration at the site. Measurable: Infrastructure fidelity and usefulness, number of collaborations. (4) A related goal is to start the EIP air quality scientist hiring process (in collaboration with Stony Brook) – subject to University permission. Measurable: a successful search
FY 20-21.goal3: Expand and Promote Renewable Energy Research at ASRC – Specifically: (1) Start the EIP renewable energy scientist hiring process - subject to University permission. Measurable: a successful search (2) Secure additional external funding to support this work (e.g. NOAA, NSF, NYSERDA. Measurable: booked research support (3) Build R&D relationships on the perfect forecast/firm power generation concepts via COE, EdESLR. Measurable: project prospects. (4) Expand ASRC’s renewable energy group’s R&D and collaborative partnerships in offshore wind. Measurable: funding/collaboration through public/private partnerships, COE engagement (5) Promote ASRC’s research portfolio in renewables through publications, presentations and outreach to public and State Government. Measurable: Numbers of publications and presentations, media and NY State awareness
FY 20-21.goal4: Expand and Promote ASRC’s portfolio in aerosol-cloud-precipitation-weather-climate interactions. Specifically: (1) To maintain and extend external research funding for various research topics on interactions among aerosols, clouds, precipitation, weather, and climate. Measured by research activity and booked research support, (2) To promote collaborations among ASRC researchers with expertise in different aspects of the complex interactions including numerical modeling, data analysis, field measurements at PSP and WFM and Mesonet, and remote sensing. Measured by enhanced collaboration and joined research proposals. (3) To explore external collaborations with NCAR scientists on model improvements and scientific investigation. Measured by formal research agreements, joint publications, and projects with partners.
FY 20-21.goal5: Expand and Promote ASRC’s portfolio in boundary layer research, including atmospheric chemistry and air quality. Specifically: (1) To promote and establish new research concerned with the planetary boundary layer (PBL) - exploiting NYS Mesonet observations. Measured by research activity and booked research support, (2) To promote new PBL research concerned atmospheric chemistry and air quality (including in an urban environment) taking advantage of the NYS Mesonet as well as the newly installed micronet in NY City. Measured by research activity and booked research support (3) To explore external collaborations with key strategic partners in these research areas (e.g. CUNY, University of Oklahoma). Measured by formal research agreements and projects with partners.

(ii) A Weather AI/ML scientific group will be formed as outlined above.

(ii) Engage further with NY State on importance of ASRC research in this domain; including more promotion of Whitepaper created in 2019 (updated if needed).
(iii) Permission to start search for EIP position; then the search committee will aggressively recruit.
FY 20-21.actions4:
(i) In addition to regular group meetings, regular strategic discussions between the Director and Fangqun Yu and other key faculty will take place to ensure we are successful; bringing in other key personnel as needed.

FY 19-20.listofIntellectualProperties: Proof of concept for at least one IP application (likely filed) by Rabi Musah on therapy that employs neutron beam was obtained using the Ion Beam Lab. Details were not provided to IBL.
FY 19-20.keynoteAddresses: IBL is a service organization. Its employees and staff do not normally make presentations at conferences.
FY 19-20.topAchievements1: Completed Phase 1 of the Extrion implanter redesign and rebuilding. We have gathered most of the materials needed for phase two (Covid has complicated this). Written 90% of the control software needed for phase two.
FY 19-20.topAchievements2:
We were able to add capabilities to the facility that expanded the value of our facility to our users.

(See details in the Goals and results section)
FY 19-20.goal1: To expand the usage of the IBL by designing and implementing methods of  specialized characterization work that can be performed by IBL staff for outside entities. This will expand both our research utility as well as our revenue opportunities.
FY 19-20.goal2: To redesign and rebuild the Extrion Implant Accelerator. This refit will increase its capabilities, allowing us to expand our research utility, and simplify its use for operators which will increase its use.
FY 19-20.goal3: Expand the capabilities of the Facility to increase its utility to a more diverse customer base.
FY 19-20.goal4: The IBL is currently working to replace support systems that have exceeded their service life in an effort to lower the overall energy consumption of the facility. It is also working on installing new control systems on the Dynamitron and the Extrion to better manage the system itself and also better manage their energy consumption. These efforts fall in line with SUNY’s overall efforts to lower the its energy consumption. As a facility dedicated to the study of the natural world it is imperative that the IBL participates in its conservation.
FY 19-20.goal5: Increase educational support at the IBL.
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented1:
The IBL has performed analysis work for industry partners like IBM, BMW, Intel, Nokomis and Radiation Dynamics. This work is in addition to the ever expanding list of outside universities that we have performed sample analysis for.

These activities help concentrate research and development efforts in new and exciting fields here in the Capital District.
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented2:
The IBL has completed the first phase of the project which was to design and have manufactured a new high voltage power supply. The design work was done in-house and the construction was done off site. 

The path forward has been outlined and materials are being purchased in preparation for phase two.
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented3:
Reconfigure the 30 degree line to produce both high and low energy neutrons.

Designed and built a new end station on the 20 degree line to attach a cryo containment vessel to expose samples provided by outside users to simulated solar wind.

These efforts have added to the overall capabilities of the IBL facility.
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented4: Some efforts have been made on this front but Staffing constraints have slowed progress.
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented5: The IBL continues to support education by providing access to the facilities in order to educate/train both graduate and undergraduate students. These efforts include graduate student training and undergraduate lab experiments to support lab classes like PHY 335.
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults1: We were able to increase revenue through the sale of characterization services to outside entities in spite of the downtime of the Extrion.
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults2:
The power supply has been incorporated into the system and functions as designed.

The phase two materials are almost all in-house (Covid has slowed this to a crawl) and the control software has been mostly written.
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults3:
We were able to produce thermal neutrons to facilitate testing of a compound developed by Prof Rabi Musah in the SUNY Albany Chemistry department. This research will be used to develop better methods of treating cancer using Boron Neutron Capture Therapy.

We were also able to produce high energy neutrons to create reference samples for  Prof Cecilia Levy in the SUNY Albany Physics department, This research was being conducted jointly with RPI and is part of an ongoing research project to detect Dark mater particles using geological samples.

We were able to utilize the 20 degree line to expose samples for the US Air Force that were being analyzed by George Nelson at RIT in collaboration with Radiation Dynamics Inc.. This research will help develop the models used by the Air Force and NASA to calculate solar wind damage experienced by satellites in earth orbit.
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults5: We now have an additional 5 grad students qualified to work at the IBL belonging to three different universities.
FY 19-20.changes2: This effort has been hampered by the current staffing deficiencies that we are working with.
FY 19-20.changes3: This effort has been hampered by the current staffing deficiencies that we are working with.
FY 19-20.changes4: This effort has been hampered by the current staffing deficiencies that we are working with.
FY 19-20.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch: The IBL has the opportunity to participate in the fields of space weather, geology, biology and material science. This would increase our research utility as well as increase our revenues.
FY 19-20.bigChallenges:
The (IBL) is composed of several experimental systems that have a wide range of sizes and complexity. Each of these systems is comprised of a collection of both mechanical and electronic components, each with its own maintenance needs and operational service life.

In order for any manufacturing or experimental system to function efficiently and extend the operational service life, each component within that system requires a well thought out, and carefully adhered to maintenance schedule. However, not adhering to the maintenance regime can, and often does lead to the premature failure of components resulting in the need for expensive repair or replacement. Unexpected component failures lead to unscheduled down time leading to the expenditure of time and capital that could otherwise be utilized to extend the capabilities of the system.

The IBL has traditionally functioned with a contingent of personnel that ensured that the systems comprising the IBL had the care and scrutiny described above. The team consisted two to three technicians and engineers to maintain the systems and implement any upgrades or refits.  This staffing level was maintained for the forty plus years that the IBL had been in existence.

The current contingent consists of one technician and a part-time project manager. This staffing level is no longer sufficient to meet the needs of the IBL and its continued operation, let alone expand and grow. As a result of the staffing shortfall, routine maintenance has been deferred resulting in unscheduled down time and avoidable expense. As a consequence, the time devoted to the unscheduled repairs further diminishes the time available for routine maintenance which leads to addition unscheduled downs. This spiraling degradation of the IBL’s capabilities over a decade of neglect has reached a near unsustainable level and needs to be addressed before the trend becomes unrecoverable. It goes without saying that if the day to day maintenance of the IBL systems are suffering, then the development and implementation of a Strategic Plan is impossible.

The current situation has already adversely affected research being performed at UAlbany as well as other Academic and Industrial affiliates. To continue on this path would eventually lead to a situation where the IBL would not be able to fulfill its Mission.
FY 19-20.resourceNeeds: The IBL requires at least one more additional full time Technician to help maintain the systems at the IBL. It would also benefit from a capital investment by the university to upgrade and modernize some of the aging components that are prone to failure. This would also lower our energy consumption which would be inline with the universities overall energy goals.
FY 19-20.strategicSuggestions: Have a modernized and efficient, fully staffed facility.
FY 19-20.otherthoughts: The IBL is a unique facility that has capabilities that are not available anywhere else in the world. Although it lies under ground and mostly unknown by the wider University population, its past impact on the development of our modern understanding of material science is profound. Moving forward, its expanded capabilities and practices should allow it to continue to contribute to our collective understanding of the universe in a very meaningful way. This of course is dependent on whether or not the IBL has the resources needed to first maintain, and then advance its capabilities.

FY 19-20.mission: The mission of the Center for Functional Genomics is to develop expertise on new and developing genomic technologies that advance and improve the understanding of biology. As part of its mission, the CFG maintains core competencies in genomics, epitranscriptomics, epigenetics and bioinformatics.
FY 19-20.vision: The Center for Functional Genomics provides state-of-the-art services that enables scientists to conduct innovative research utilizing resources for which cost, operational investment, and expertise is most efficiently and effectively supported as a shared resource, fostering the growth of biotechnology at the University at Albany and throughout the Capital Region.
FY 19-20.annualBudget: We had a 37% increase in our revenues (including collections) even with a decrease in our FTEs. Currently we have 2.5 FTEs as laboratory staff and 1.5 FTEs as admin support

FY 19-20.topAchievements2: Development of methods for SARS-Cov2 detection: The lab has been part of a global effort to develop a cheaper assay using isothermal amplification (LAMP) and saliva samples. We were recipients of seed funding from SUNY that resulted in an R21 application.

FY 19-20.noteworthyResults1: Last year we conducted over 44 sequencing experiments with over 500 samples and this work has resulted in 13 publications. Multiple PIs in Biology have successfully secured extramural grant funding based on data generated in our core
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults2: We successfully graduated 4 UG students through the Bioinstrumentation program. We also trained 1 UG student (HVCC), 3 UA graduate students and 1 postdoc in the lab
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults3:
increased # publications
increased grant submissions
in spite of our aging instrumentation, we  were still able to run 465 microarrays for investigators
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults4: We still have the Sanger sequencer (circa 2005) and Affymetrix GeneChip systems (Circa 2003) working and providing services to multiple investigators. We have developed other methods like Cell line authentication and Methylation analysis on the Sanger sequencer.
FY 19-20.changes3:
Need to update instrumentation in lab to be able to provide new cutting edge technologies that are gaining popularity
Older instrumentation have errors that result in us having to repeat the assays multiple time increasing out process cost and time.
FY 19-20.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch: The COVID pandemic while catastrophic  is also an opportunity for CFG to target funding for molecular assay development. The methods we currently use can be retooled to get us involved in infectious disease surveillance, metagenomics and areas for developing biomedical science and engineering
FY 19-20.bigChallenges:
The equipment at CFG is aging with some at 15-18 yrs. Our latest instrument is now 5 yrs old and going to be obsolete soon. Newer technologies allow for cost efficiencies and are gaining popularity. If we do not invest in capital equipment, we will loose our resourcefulness to the scientific community.
With the past RIFs that have been necessary to address the ongoing budget crises, it becomes harder to complete projects if a staff member is ill. Having a liquid handling station would help alleviate this and would also prevent current staff from work-related health issues like carpal tunnel
FY 19-20.resourceNeeds:
Instrumentation upgrades to keep up with technology
Robotics to alleviate load on human work force
A more robust biostatistics and bioinformatics program at the university where we can tap in to. The data generated by our experiments is complex and deters faculty from doing them which in turn makes them less competitive in grant funding.
FY 19-20.strategicSuggestions:
More partnerships with other departments like Biology, Engineering
More collaborative ventures with neighboring area Institutions- we are already a regional resource
More partnerships with area biotechnology companies (fee for service, STTRs)
FY 19-20.otherthoughts:
We write a lot of support letters for faculty at the university but never find out if the grant was funded (unless we were listed for effort). It would be helpful to have a system where we could track this.
It would be helpful to have a better system to track invoice payments. Often our records are waiting for payments to show up on RF or State accounts
It would be good to have a small unit at the university that can refurbish/maintaine scientific equipment. The service contracts on our instruments are expensive but needed to validate the reliability of the complex experiments that are in themselves very expensive both in time and costs.

FY 19-20.mission: CTG UAlbany – formerly known as the Center for Technology in Government at the State University of New York (SUNY) at Albany – is a research institute that works with governments worldwide to help transform public service through innovative approaches to, and applications of, technology, management, and policy. Established in 1993, we pursue new ways to use technology to address practical problems of information management and service delivery in government. CTG UAlbany has collaborated with hundreds of domestic and international researchers on understanding and applying emerging technologies. At the same time, CTG UAlbany has worked with scores of local, state, federal, and international government bodies as a trusted advisor and facilitator of management and policy decisions to govern the use of new technologies as tools for public service transformation.
FY 19-20.vision: Work with governments worldwide transforming public services through innovations in technology, policy and management.
FY 19-20.annualBudget: CTG UAlbany’s financial stability over its 26 years in service as an applied research Institute, has been based on its tenured and experienced faculty, researchers, professional administration and finance and project staff. CTG’s subject matter expertise has an ability to continue to build capacity and capability through its projects and research, while generating the necessary project revenues to support CTG’s operational expenses of over $550K annually.  These annually generated revenues allow CTG to support several project support positions, external UAlbany research faculty, graduate students and its programs or work through MOUs, revenue contracts and research agreements with partners both through the Research Foundation such as federal agencies, corporate sponsors, and international governments or through the University at Albany with state agencies, municipal and local governments, state authorities, and not for profits.   CTG’s FY 2019 PSR state allocation of $971,049  supported 12 FTE’s, during this  fiscal year CTG lost 2 PSR funded positons, one position to WFP committee review of Communications Manager denied for rehiring at $51,000 and the second position to the 15 % state reduction of Sr. Project Assistant at $49,993, totaling $100,993 in permanent state PSR funding.  CTG’s professional staff funded by the PSR allocation are engaged in CTG’s development of new programs and innovations, projects and research proposals, day to day operations, business development activities, academic and community engagement, and other related outreach and dissemination activities within the University and globally.   In 2019, CTG UAlbany conducted 8 Research Foundation sponsored projects and 3 state agency, local government, and not for profits projects simultaneously.  CTG UAlbany revenue generates annually, through various sources, to support CTG’s IFR operational expenditures which for FY 2019 totaled $510,581. CTG’s revenue generation through its various projects supports its annual operational budget of OTPS which includes the following expense categories of  facilities costs (e.g. rent, taxes, utilities), phones, computer equipment and software, graduate students, temp service and term positions, supplies, service contracts, business travel, staff development, conferences, and any other non-PSR  expense needed to operate CTG UAlbany. CTG doesn’t receive an annual OTPS allocation from the Division of Research, instead it revenue generates on its own to support CTG’s OTPS budget.  A unique aspect of CTG’s financial/business model relative to most academic departments and other research units; is that CTG not only relies on its traditional research funded projects, but has many state agency projects, under state MOUs and revenue contracts. These state projects are a part of the strategic business development and financial planning that is the necessary support our annual operational budget. Within this template provided, it doesn’t allow a place for CTG UAlbany to report those state MOUs and Revenue contracts pending, as is the case for pending submitted RF proposals. Therefore, the information is provided here in the narrative.  CTG has several MOUs pending with state agencies such as: 1. NYS BOE’s Future elections at $310,000, 2. NYS BOE Election Remediation Risk at $35,000, along with several other opportunities in the business development, additional work on the project with the United Arab Emirates estimated at an additional $40K and new work with the United Nations for a round two which is in the business development stages. Also, we are submitting a preliminary proposal to IMLS related focused on exploring the role of public libraries as intermediaries of innovation in local and regional contexts.

FY 19-20.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch:
We believe that working with local governments in the Capital Region, New York State, and throughout the country as a big opportunity to advance our research. There continues to be a federal, state, and industry focus on the area of smart cities/communities and investment of information and communication technologies (e.g. machine learning, artificial intelligence, data analytics) at the local government to help improve government operations and provide public services. Given our expertise and research interest in the policy, management, and technology dimensions of information and technology use by governments at all levels, CTG UAlbany can continue to make significant contributions in this area for next 1-5 years.  
We continue to see working with state agencies in New York and beyond as another big opportunity to advance our research. As state governments and individual state agencies try to modernize older and legacy information systems and adopt new data management and analysis techniques there is a lot of opportunity to apply CTG UAlbany's existing expertise and conduct new externally funded research in this area.
We are actively pursuing research project partnerships with faculty and professional researchers at CEHC and ASRC. We see a lot of opportunity to collaborate on policy, technology, and management issues in the emergency preparedness, homeland and cyber security, and weather domains and produce competitive and innovative research proposals.
FY 19-20.bigChallenges: Due to professionals staff leaving and difficulty in rehiring due to current budget constraints, CTG UAlbany has seen a significant decrease in non faculty professional researchers who help manage and provide support to our research and other projects. This is impacting the number and size of projects we can conduct simultaneously.
FY 19-20.resourceNeeds: CTG UAlbany is actively seeking space on campus that will allow ups to be closer to our students, fellow faculty researchers, and campus administration. In addition, space on campus will allow CTG to dedicate more of its external reseach funding dollars to support paid undergradute and graduate interns and assistantships
FY 19-20.strategicSuggestions: Continue to invest in support for proposal development and pre and post award support in general. Also, we think that it is very important to expand the staff and expertise of the UAlbany technology development office. Resources and expertise in this area are critical to helping CTG UAlbany and other researchers at UAlbany determine if and how their research findings can be protected and commercialized.

FY 20-21.mission: CTG UAlbany – formerly known as the Center for Technology in Government at the State University of New York (SUNY) at Albany – is a research institute that works with governments worldwide to help transform public service through innovative approaches to, and applications of, technology, management, and policy. Established in 1993, we pursue new ways to use technology to address practical problems of information management and service delivery in government. CTG UAlbany has collaborated with hundreds of domestic and international researchers on understanding and applying emerging technologies. At the same time, CTG UAlbany has worked with scores of local, state, federal, and international government bodies as a trusted advisor and facilitator of management and policy decisions to govern the use of new technologies as tools for public service transformation.
FY 20-21.vision: Work with governments worldwide transforming public services through innovations in technology, policy and management.
FY 20-21.annualBudget: CTG UAlbany’s financial stability over its 26 years in service as an applied research Institute, has been based on its tenured and experienced faculty, researchers, professional administration and finance and project staff. CTG’s subject matter expertise has an ability to continue to build capacity and capability through its projects and research, while generating the necessary project revenues to support CTG’s operational expenses of over $550K annually.  These annually generated revenues allow CTG to support several project support positions, external UAlbany research faculty, graduate students and its programs or work through MOUs, revenue contracts and research agreements with partners both through the Research Foundation such as federal agencies, corporate sponsors, and international governments or through the University at Albany with state agencies, municipal and local governments, state authorities, and not for profits.   CTG’s FY 2019 PSR state allocation of $971,049  supported 12 FTE’s, during this  fiscal year CTG lost 2 PSR funded positons, one position to WFP committee review of Communications Manager denied for rehiring at $51,000 and the second position to the 15 % state reduction of Sr. Project Assistant at $49,993, totaling $100,993 in permanent state PSR funding.  CTG’s professional staff funded by the PSR allocation are engaged in CTG’s development of new programs and innovations, projects and research proposals, day to day operations, business development activities, academic and community engagement, and other related outreach and dissemination activities within the University and globally.   In 2019, CTG UAlbany conducted 8 Research Foundation sponsored projects and 3 state agency, local government, and not for profits projects simultaneously.  CTG UAlbany revenue generates annually, through various sources, to support CTG’s IFR operational expenditures which for FY 2019 totaled $510,581. CTG’s revenue generation through its various projects supports its annual operational budget of OTPS which includes the following expense categories of  facilities costs (e.g. rent, taxes, utilities), phones, computer equipment and software, graduate students, temp service and term positions, supplies, service contracts, business travel, staff development, conferences, and any other non-PSR  expense needed to operate CTG UAlbany. CTG doesn’t receive an annual OTPS allocation from the Division of Research, instead it revenue generates on its own to support CTG’s OTPS budget.  A unique aspect of CTG’s financial/business model relative to most academic departments and other research units; is that CTG not only relies on its traditional research funded projects, but has many state agency projects, under state MOUs and revenue contracts. These state projects are a part of the strategic business development and financial planning that is the necessary support our annual operational budget. Within this template provided, it doesn’t allow a place for CTG UAlbany to report those state MOUs and Revenue contracts pending, as is the case for pending submitted RF proposals. Therefore, the information is provided here in the narrative.  CTG has several MOUs pending with state agencies such as: 1. NYS BOE’s Future elections at $310,000, 2. NYS BOE Election Remediation Risk at $35,000, along with several other opportunities in the business development, additional work on the project with the United Arab Emirates estimated at an additional $40K and new work with the United Nations for a round two which is in the business development stages. Also, we are submitting a preliminary proposal to IMLS related focused on exploring the role of public libraries as intermediaries of innovation in local and regional contexts.

FY 19-20.mission: CSDA's mission is to facilitate and organize population research and education of the highest caliber. It seeks to accomplish this mission by creating a stimulating and cohesive intellectual environment conducive to the development of multidisciplinary population scholarship, particularly on the Center’s signature themes of spatial inequalities and vulnerable populations.  Key areas of research include:  health and health disparities, immigration, risks to youth and adolescents, spatial inequalities and migration, American families, and social resources and vulnerabilities of the elderly.
FY 19-20.vision: Our vision is to increase our funding portfolio, forge linkages with other units on campus that don't know about CSDA, attract students from underrepresented minority groups to engage in population-based research, and conduct strategic planning to solidify our larger vision moving forward.
FY 19-20.annualBudget: At this point, we have no other sources of budget for our half-time employee, Jin-Wook Lee, who we share with the Lewis Mumford Center (AVAIL).  We are working on finding other sources of funding for Mr. Lee.

FY 19-20.otherActivities:
CSDA associate Zai Liang, along CSDA associate Glenn Deane and other co-authors received the 2020 Louis Wirth Best Article Award from International Migration Section of ASA for their paper on spatial diffusion of low-skilled Chinese immigrants in the United States. Full citation of the article is below
Liang, Zai, Jiejin Li, Glenn Deane, Zhen Li, and Bo Zhou. 2018. “From Chinatown to Everytown: New Patterns of Employment for Low-skilled Chinese Immigrants in the United States.” Social Forces 97(2):893-919
FY 19-20.topAchievements1: We have begun rebuilding the leadership team of CSDA.  Dr. Friedman was officially appointed as Director on November 1, 2019. Since 2018, we had no official director. The COVID-19 pandemic put things on hold, but we have re-organized our leadership team and have set goals to fulfill this upcoming year.
FY 19-20.topAchievements2: We have begun work on building an infrastructure to include undergraduate students of color in population-science research with our Research Associates.
FY 19-20.goal1:
Our first priority is to increase our funding portfolio, with an emphasis on applying for grants in the Population Dynamics Branch (PDB) of NICHD

Expanding funding in the latter agency will increase our ability to be successful in being funded by a future center grant from NICHD. This priority fits directly with the Strategic Plan’s goal, in the Research Excellence area, of increasing the ratio of faculty with research grants. To achieve this goal, we plan to invite a program officer from NICHD to discuss the funding priorities with our associates as well as others on campus. In addition, we will organize a meeting with our faculty associates from the School of Education, Sociology, the School of Public Health, and researchers at the New York State Department of Health to provide information to CSDA associates, graduate students, and the university community about datasets (restricted and non-restricted – like Upstate Kids, National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent to Adult Health, and NY State data) that could lead to funding opportunities for researchers in CSDA as well as across the university. We will measure our success by gauging the increase in applications for funding to NICHD and other funding agencies.
FY 19-20.goal2:
Our second main priority is to forge linkages with other units on campus that do not know about CSDA but could potentially benefit from alignments with population-based researchers and from whom CSDA associates could benefit.

None of our CSDA associates are currently from the College of Emergency Preparedness, Homeland Security, and Cybersecurity (CEHC) or from the Department of Atmospheric and Environmental Sciences. However, the research that is conducted in both units is focused on disasters and climate change, which has implications for the migration and the health and well-being of populations, two of the main foci of CSDA. Forging collaborations across programs is one of the main priorities of the Strategic Plan in the area of Research Excellence. To achieve this goal, we plan to hold a meeting with key researchers in CEHC and the Department of Atmospheric and Environmental Sciences and have short flash presentations so that all parties involved will get to know about each other’s current research interests. We will measure our success by gauging future collaborations sparked by this meeting and potentially others in the future.
FY 19-20.goal3:
Our third priority is to explore ways to attract students, particularly underrepresented minorities, to engage in population-based research, enhance student experiences of those already engaged in population-based research, and ultimately, through the former endeavors, grow a workforce to assist CSDA associates and others in the local community and government with their research.

To achieve this goal, we will target funding opportunities from the National Science Foundation (NSF) INCLUDES Planning Grants (https://www.nsf.gov/funding/pgm_summ.jsp?pims_id=505679) due on July 13, 2020 as well as NSF’s Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) due on August 26, 2020. With respect to the NSF INCLUDES program, Deedee Bennett from CEHC has acquired funding through this mechanism, and we will draw on her expertise in achieving this goal, which will also work well in fulfilling our goals to achieve priority 2 (described above). We will target StAR based funding to get short-term assistance in laying the groundwork for these proposals. The basis of these proposals will be to leverage our multidisciplinary research capacity to create a hub that will connect students to research opportunities at UAlbany, local and state governments, and private industry. CSDA will provide research training, networking, and professionalization opportunities in the area of population-based science as it relates to the data revolution that links the disciplines together. CSDA would position itself to become UAlbany’s core for statistical consulting and training across units and seek to generate funds from others seeking these services. Our initial success will be based upon our ability to acquire funding from NSF.
FY 19-20.goal4: One of our other priorities is to maintain connections with other population-based research centers in New York State and elsewhere. CSDA and the School of Public Health at Albany have partnered with Cornell and Syracuse Universities in participating annually in an Upstate Population conference. We will continue to engage in this endeavor because it facilitates connections with neighboring research universities and promotes collaborations that can lead to extramural funding. CSDA will also continue to be a member of the Association of Population Centers (APC) and participate in APC annual meetings. Currently, there is an initiative among centers in APC to work with each other on an NIH-sponsored training grant. CSDA is engaged in this endeavor. Samantha Friedman will be the Primary Leader on this initiative and will represent CSDA at the APC meeting as well as the Upstate Population conference.
FY 19-20.goal5: Another priority is for CSDA to engage in its own Strategic Planning during the next year and develop its vision for the next five years so that its mission and goals are clearer, and inclusive of all associates, and aligned with the vision of the University. To this end, we will hold Executive Committee meetings to plan a retreat that we will hold within the next year (by November 2020), and within six months after the retreat, we will finalize a strategic plan document with our vision. Samantha Friedman will be the Primary Leader on this initiative.
FY 19-20.actions1:
To achieve this goal, we will:
1) have a colloquium series this year to showcase successful NICHD grantees from other universities and their research;

2)  organize meetings around each of our core themes -- 1) population health; 2) immigration and internal migration; and 3) spatial inequalities -- with our faculty associates working in those areas to identify opportunities for future collaboration as it fits with the Population Dynamics Branch of PDB.
FY 19-20.actions2: To achieve this goal, we plan to hold a meeting with key researchers in CEHC and the Department of Atmospheric and Environmental Sciences and have short flash presentations so that all parties involved will get to know about each other’s current research interests. Relatedly, we want to build a data infrastructure by amassing data on climate and disasters to facilitate the research of our associates.
FY 19-20.actions3: To achieve this goal, we will: 1) identify our associates who are working on research with undergraduates; 2) make CSDA activities more visible to undergraduates at UAlbany by encouraging their participation in our colloquium series and by holding virtual events surrounding Census 2020; 3) network with other departments who do not know about CSDA but whose students could be of great value to CSDA associates (e.g., data science, statistics, and information science); and 4) form a small group of CSDA associates that will collaborate to write a proposal for the National Science Foundation Research Experience for Undergraduates due in August 2021.
FY 19-20.metrics1: We will measure our success by gauging the increase in applications for funding to NICHD and other funding agencies.
FY 19-20.metrics2: We will measure our success by gauging future collaborations sparked by this meeting and potentially others in the future.
FY 19-20.metrics3: Our success will be based upon our ability to attract undergraduate students to participate in our events; to involve more undergraduate and graduate students of color in the research of CSDA associates; and to apply for funding via the NSF REU mechanism.
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented1: We have encouraged our associates to apply for NICHD grants through the Population Dynamics Branch.  We also have renewed our application to maintain our access in our coldroom lab to the restricted data from the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent to Adult Health. This access allows graduate students to work on PhDs using these data, which makes them more competitive on the job market.
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented2: Because of the pandemic, we could not fulfill this goal.
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented3: We have acquired a successful application to the NSF REU from another institution.  To be competitive, we need to have a track record in working with undergraduates.  At the end of this reporting period (6/30/20) we advertised positions in CSDA via the work-study program to achieve this goal.
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented4: Several CSDA associates participated in the Upstate Population conference last fall.  We have also participated in APC meetings.  We are involved in an NIH R25 training grant, called NextGenPop, that is being submitted on 9/25/20, although we are not a primary sponsor.
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented5: With the pandemic there was no way to hold a retreat.
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults1: We have increased our applications to NICHD.
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults4:
We are involved in an NIH R25 training grant, called NextGenPop, that is being submitted on 9/25/20, although we are not a primary sponsor.  The first funding cycle will involve five population centers, including Cornell. We are partnering with Cornell to recruit undergraduates from UAlbany, and we will participate in the summer training program there if this is funded.  By working closely with Cornell, we hope to be a main center in the next five-year grant cycle. 

CSDA Associate Ben Shaw just got funding for the Center for Aging and Policy Studies (CAPS), which is an outgrowth of our collaborations with Cornell and Syracuse.  The focus of CAPS is on aging, but it will benefit CSDA associates by facilitating collaboration across these three centers, all of which have expertise in demography.  I will serve on the Advisory Board of CAPS.
FY 19-20.changes2:
This year we are hosting a small colloquium series, and one of the presenters, Dr. Elizabeth Fussell, is the editor of Population and Environment.  She is engaged in climate-based population research focused on climate impacts on migration, which is a timely topic -- https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/09/15/magazine/climate-crisis-migration-america.html. Dr. Fussell has received funds from PDB at NICHD.

We would like to build the capacity of our Research Associates to easily access climate-based data to engage in demographic research. We have reached out twice to colleagues in CEHC with no response. We will reach out to Chris Thorncroft to get his input.
FY 19-20.changes3: We are continuing to work towards the goal of applying for an NSF REU next year.  We are gathering information on all of our associates who are working on research with undergraduates, and we will hold meetings with associates who are interested in working on this NSF REU initiatve.
FY 19-20.changes5: Last year's Executive Committee was too large and proved ineffective to make regular decisions about CSDA.  Over the summer we split the committee.  We now have seven people on the Executive Committee, and the other members will serve on the Advisory Board.  The Executive Committee is meeting monthly to establish this year's goals for CSDA.
FY 19-20.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch: Grow the data support staff at the university. We have Master's degrees in Biostatistics, Data Analytics, Econometrics, and Information Science, among other fields. Yet, we have no infrastructure for researchers to get assistance with their data analyses and statistics. CSDA plans to capitalize on this gap since the university has done nothing in this area. CHSR cannot fill this gap. They are understaffed and do not have the talent in statistical analyses necessary to tackle more difficult research questions.
FY 19-20.bigChallenges: Lack of a research infrastructure in data analytics. If researchers have to obtain data, clean data, run analyses, there's little time left to write grants and publish papers. We need mid- level people to do the former tasks and leave the big ideas and science generation for the faculty.
FY 19-20.resourceNeeds: We would value getting an administrative assistant for my unit and/or a graduate assistant line.
FY 19-20.strategicSuggestions: We want to get more information about how to access climate/disaster related data.  This would ease our associates' abilities to pursue research on demographic events -- migration and mortality -- and relate them to climate change.  We would greatly appreciate the VPR's assistance in helping us forge linkages with other units on campus.  I've reached out to CEHC twice and got no response.  If this comes from the VPR, other units might be more receptive.
FY 19-20.otherthoughts: It would be useful to hold a Coffee Hour and have researchers from across campus talk about climate/disaster sources of data.  There are units on campus working on this, but having a coordinated effort for researchers to learn about these sources would be of tremendous value.

FY 19-20.mission: The mission of the Institute for Health and the Environment is to promote interdisciplinary research and training among faculty from the various schools and colleges of UAlbany. While this is certainly true for local and regional activities, a major focus of the Institute is to promote international research and training activities.
FY 19-20.vision: The mission of the Institute for Health and the Environment is to promote interdisciplinary research and training among faculty from the various schools and colleges of UAlbany.  This is true for local and regional actions, especially with outreach to communities organizations, but with a major focus on international research and training activites.
FY 19-20.annualBudget:
The Institute is poor.  We depend primarily on federal grants.  Current we have only one, but with one pending.  In the past a major source of funding was monies coming from outside activities such as expert witness work, but the University has prohibited us from putting these funds into our RF account.  This is a major blow to our fiscal viability.  


Current support is state salaries for two full time employees plus remaining funds in an RF account that we now cannot add to.

FY 19-20.mission: The mission of the New York State Mesonet (NYSM) is to serve the state of New York by providing the best meteorological data, the best products, and the best services possible with the goal of saving lives and property while building a smart weather economy. At its core, the NYSM is a highly dedicated, cross-disciplinary team aspiring to set the worldwide standard of excellence for data quality. With its unique focus on research to operations, preventive maintenance, and state-of-the-art quality control efforts, the NYSM utilizes these high quality weather data to create end products designed to improve forecast accuracy, reduce uncertainty, and mitigate harm.
FY 19-20.vision:
The vision of the New York State Mesonet is to become a national center, collaborating with
government, academic, and commercial partners, to educate and solve real-world problems in
agriculture, emergency management, energy, public health, and transportation, improving the well being and livelihood for all.

FY 19-20.topAchievements1: The number of funded Mesonet-related proposals jumped from 2 to 9 during the 2019-2020 season, totaling over $1M.
FY 19-20.topAchievements2: The number of active collaborations with external academic, state and federal agencies has continued to grow, now including ongoing activities with ESF/Syracuse, Cornell, Dep. of Health, DEC, NWS, USGS, and others.
FY 19-20.goal1: 1. To raise enough funding to maintain current staffing.
FY 19-20.goal2: 2. To ensure that the NYS Mesonet's network uptime exceeded 95%.
FY 19-20.goal3: 3. To expand research collaborations and partnerships with state agencies.
FY 19-20.actions1:
(a) Continued improvement in data quality control software.
(b) Continued training of field staff.
(c) Continued sensor rotation of aging sensors and equipment.
FY 19-20.actions2:
(a) Lead the writing of several proposals to federal and state RFPs.
(b) Aid UAlbany and external NYS Mesonet partners in support of their proposals. 
(c) Expand and deepen ongoing collaborations.
FY 19-20.actions3:
(a) Make peer-reviewed journal writing a specific focus for some research activities.
(b) Expand web/Facebook/Twitter presence.
(c) Expand media opportunities for the Mesonet.
FY 19-20.metrics1: All data are archived and daily statistics are compiled to record the percentage of all data received in real-time.  We have a detailed record of all station uptime percentages for all periods.
FY 19-20.metrics2:
(a) Track the number of proposals submitted from the NYS Mesonet.
(b) Track the amount of grant funding from federal, state, and other sources.
(c) Track the number of proposals including NYS Mesonet funding.
FY 19-20.metrics3:
1. Track the number of journal articles submitted for peer review.
2. Track the number of formal publications referencing Mesonet.
3. Track the number of followers on Facebook/Twitter/web.
4. Track the number and frequency of media stories following Mesonet.
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented1: Worked closely with ASRC, DAES, the National Mesonet Program, and external agencies to ensure funding sources were maintained.
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented2: We continued expanding our automated quality control software; continued field technician training; and continued working with vendors to improve and upgrade sensing equipment.
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented3: Worked with ASRC, DAES and the Center of Excellence in Weather Analytics with a focused effort to initiate new research programs using NYS Mesonet data.
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults1: Approximately $1.3M was raised to support the NYS Mesonet during the fiscal year, which allowed the staff to be retained without interruption.
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults2: The fiscal year uptime of the network exceeded 99%, far exceeding expectations.
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults3: Significant progress was achieved with a number of initiatives, involving the NYS DOT, NYS Thruway, Dep. of Public Health, state utilities and others.  These programs continue to gain momentum and broad support.
FY 19-20.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch: No limit to the number of opportunities that the NYS Mesonet presents to a wide variety of industries statewide.
FY 19-20.bigChallenges: Resources.  Much like a start-up business, certain products need to be created to garner initial interest.  Additional financial resources are needed in order to develop value-added products that many end-users require.  The "raw materials" produced by the NYS Mesonet are high quality; the final step is to create products that users need and understand.
FY 19-20.resourceNeeds: Steady financial support to ensure experienced, well qualified staff are retained and that the sensors can be proactively maintained.
FY 19-20.strategicSuggestions:
Once a bedrock of financial support is ensured, research will grow naturally and exponentially as more and more users become aware of this excellent resource. 
Education is one key sector; all school entities (public, private, home) can benefit from this key resource.

FY 19-20.mission: The Center for Human Services Research is dedicated to developing empirically based knowledge to improve the design and delivery of services that address social issues and meet community needs. We conduct evaluation research and design information systems to inform policymakers and service providers across a broad spectrum of fields. The Center for Human Services Research values integrity in its research and is dedicated to providing timely, accurate, and non-biased information to guide best practice in the human services.
FY 19-20.vision: To be the leading university-based research center in the nation that provides leaders and practitioners with empirically based knowledge and technological innovations to create a better world.
FY 19-20.listOfPublications:
1. Cumulative socio-contextual risk and child abuse potential in parents of young children: Can social support buffer the impact? Lucy McGoron, Moira Riley, Laura Scaramella, Child and Family Social Work, June 2020
2.  Sustained Impact on Parenting Practices: Year 7 Findings from the Healthy Famlies New York Randomized Controlled Trial, Kiristen Kirkland, Eunju Lee, Carolyn Smith, Rose Greene, Prevention Science, Volume 21, May 2020
3. Engaging At Risk Fathers in Home Visiting Services: Effects on Program Retention and Father Involvement, Sandra McGinnis, Rose Greene, Kristen Kirkland, Child and Adolescent Social Work Journal, July 2019
FY 19-20.topAchievements1:
Project: Evaluation of the Medicaid Redesign Team (MRT) Supportive Housing Initiative
Project Leads: Sandra McGinnis, Margaret Gullick, Mir Nahid Mahmud, Lauren Polvere, Chris Rees, Maile Ray
The Center for Human Services Research (CHSR) conducted an evaluation to assess the implementation, impact, effectiveness and cost savings of a Medicaid Redesign Team Supportive Housing (MRT-SH) Initiative. The MRT-SH Initiative was designed to increase the availability of affordable supportive housing for high–utilizers of Medicaid who are homeless or living in institutional settings as a way to improve health outcomes and reduce Medicaid cost growth. The rigorously designed study found the following positive findings: a significant treatment effect for the average number of ED visits, the average number of primary care visits, utilization related to behavioral health and housing-sensitive conditions, and reductions in potentially preventable ED use.  Furthermore, when non-Medicaid costs (such as homeless shelter stays) were introduced into the analysis, the MRT-SH initiative showed an overall net savings even after program costs.
FY 19-20.topAchievements2:
Project: Evaluation of the City of Albany Summer Youth Employment Program
Project Leads: Sandra McGinnis, Felix Quinones-Nieves, Susan Ehrhard-Dietzel
The Center for Human Services Research conducted an evaluation of the Albany City Summer Youth Employment (SYEP) Program. The team analyzed data from the City School District of Albany, and administered surveys of participating youth and employers. Findings revealed positive impacts in a number of areas, including academic success and skill development. Specifically participants were more likely than non-participants to graduate from high school, with a greater effect on graduation rates for non-white, non-Hispanic/Latino students and for students with GPAs in the lower 20% of CSDA students. A majority of youth reported that SYEP had helped them in developing skills related to problem-solving, critical thinking, time management, and employment preparation.

At its core, the NYSM is a highly dedicated, cross-disciplinary team aspiring to set the worldwide standard of excellence for data quality. FY 21-22.topAchievements1: Design and deployment of a $1M, 17-station urban network across New York City for Consolidated Edison, Inc.  These data are used for monitoring climate and for use in short-term utility operations.
FY 21-22.topAchievements2: Design and deployment of a 12-station solar measurement network across the Hudson River Valley in collaboration with NYSERDA and regional utilities.  These data will be used to optimize data usage by utilities for integration of renewable solar energy production.
FY 21-22.topAchievements3: Operate and maintain 180+ station New York State Mesonet with an uptime of > 99%. During 2020-2021, the NYSM has incorporated its own Calibration Laboratory, which is now fully functional.
FY 21-22.topAchievements4: Secured $400K in federal funding for the NYSM National Profiler Network for the 2020-2021 fiscal year.  The NYSM is establishing a national testbed for the development, testing, and evaluation of ground-based vertical profiling technologies.
FY 21-22.topAchievements5: The NYSM, in collaboration with university and external partners, submitted 14 proposals during the 2020-2021 fiscal year. These were submitted to NSF, NASA, NIH, DOE, and NOAA.

FY 21-22.goal2: To lead and support grant sponsored research of at least $1 million during the 2020-2021 season.
FY 21-22.goal3: Expand NYS Mesonet communications through increased peer-reviewed publications and media.
FY 21-22.actions1: The above goal was accomplished.  The NYSM continues to maintain its 180 stations, plus additional collaborative networks, including the 12-station roadside network, 12-station solar network, 17-station urban network, and 1 DOT wind site. The NYSM achieved 99%+ uptime during the year period.
FY 21-22.actions2: Achieved.  The NYSM realized > $1M in external project research.  Specifically, the NYSM collaborated with Consolidated Edison, Inc. to design and deploy a 17-station urban weather network across NYC.
FY 21-22.actions3: The NYSM completed its first overview paper with publication of a description of its network in a peer-reviewed journal.  Additional papers were submitted for review.
FY 21-22.metrics1: The NYSM achieved 99% uptime during the year.
FY 21-22.metrics2: The NYSM achieved > $1M in external projects.
FY 21-22.metrics3: The NYSM completed its first journal publication, with 3 additional papers written and either submitted for review or are ready for submission.
FY 21-22.timeframe1: The NYSM achieved 99%+ uptime during the 01/01/20 - 12/31/20 period.  The NYSM has continued to record 99%+ during 2021.
FY 21-22.timeframe2: The NYSM achieved > $1M in external projects between June 2020 and present.
FY 21-22.timeframe3: The papers were published and/or submitted for review since June 2020.
FY 21-22.actionsImplemented1: To continue to achieve this level of performance, the NYSM has developed its own Calibration Laboratory.  This new Cal Lab allows the NYSM to calibrate its own sensors, providing a more cost-effective and faster turnaround on sensor calibrations and repairs.
FY 21-22.actionsImplemented3: Set aside time for publication of results.  Continue to write and submit additional papers for publication.
FY 21-22.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch: NYSM is leading the development of a national Profiling Testbed, and associated with that, is a co-PI on two large nationally-led proposals.  Many opportunities to expand collaborations across the transportation, health, agriculture, and energy sectors.
FY 21-22.bigChallenges: The NYSM requires publicly funded financial support, and so far, has received no support from NYS.  The NYSM supports many state agencies, and so the lack of financial support from the state has severely limited what NYSM has been able to accomplish.
FY 21-22.resourceNeeds: The NYSM has operated on a budget of ~ $1M, but requires an annual budget of ~$2.5M.  The NYSM needs several additional staff in order to expand its collaborations with external partners.
FY 21-22.strategicSuggestions: The NYSM has weather operations in every county and borough across New York State.  Local political leaders could be approached to support those operations within their districts.  Furthermore, data generated from these stations can be made available to local schools, if support could be obtained to do so.

FY 21-22.mission: CSDA's mission is to facilitate and organize population research and education of the highest caliber. It seeks to accomplish this mission by creating a stimulating and cohesive intellectual environment conducive to the development of multidisciplinary population scholarship, particularly on the Center's signature themes of spatial inequalities and vulnerable populations. Key areas of research include: health and health disparities, immigration, risks to youth and adolescents, spatial inequalities and migration, American families, and social resources and vulnerabilities of the elderly.
FY 21-22.vision: Our vision is to increase our funding portfolio, forge linkages with other units on campus that don't know about CSDA, attract students from underrepresented minority groups to engage in population-based research, and conduct strategic planning to solidify our larger vision moving forward.
FY 21-22.annualBudget: At this point, we have no other sources of budget for our half-time employee, Jin-Wook Lee, who we share with the Lewis Mumford Center (AVAIL). We have three grants pending that will pay for a small portion of Jin's services. Two have gotten fundable scores and are pending final review, which should come in June/July 2022. The other was just put under review at NIEHS in April.
FY 21-22.publicationsActual: 233 peer reviewed articles -- not sure how many specifically cite CSDA
