FY 21-22.otherActivities: DK -- we haven't collected these data
FY 21-22.graduatePhdStudentsActual: DK -- department related and not specifically to CSDA
FY 21-22.topAchievements1: We have three active grants -- two R03s and an R21 subaward -- from the Population Dynamics Branch (PDB) of the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD). We have another R03 grant that has been revised and resubmitted for review under PDB. With a few more grants from PDB, CSDA will be competitive for Center grant funding. These grants are in addition to the $4 million in grants acquired by our Research Associates.
FY 21-22.topAchievements2: CSDA Executive Committee members Friedman and Lin have budgeted in the CSDA GIS Core in extramural grant proposals. Two grant applications have fundable scores and will likely be funded, although the final word will come in June/July 2022. We have one additional proposal that was recently submitted to NIEHS. In the future, we want to encourage other CSDA Associates to submit grants and budget in the services of the GIS core.
FY 21-22.topAchievements3: CSDA had a very successful colloquium series this year. We celebrated CSDA's 40th anniversary with a colloquium by former CSDA Dr. Richard Alba on his book "The Great Demographic Illusion: Majority, Minority, and the Expanding American Mainstream." The event was attended by over 100 participants. Dr. Shao Lin gave a talk in December on "Independent and Joint Effects of Extreme Weather Events and Power Outage on Multiple Health Outcomes in New York State." It was attended by 30 people. In February, Dr. Lin's doctoral student, Xinlei Deng, presented his work on "Identifying the Joint Impacts of Sun Radiation, Temperature, Humidity, and Rain Duration on Mental Disorders in New York State Using the Mesonet Weather Monitoring System." It was attended by 25 people. Finally, in March, we had Dr. Clark Gray from the Geography Department at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill present his work on "Measuring and Addressing Social Vulnerability to Climate Change." It was attended by 30 people.
FY 21-22.topAchievements4: At CSDA's 40th anniversary celebration, we successfully launched a fundraising campaign to raise money to create an award in honor of our former director Dr. Stewart Tolnay. He was the first director to acquire funding via a population infrastructural grant from NICHD in 1997, which was 25 years ago. We raised about $5000 and created the Stewart E. Tolnay Award Outstanding Graduate Student Research Paper Award. We will be making the first award in June. We will continue our fundraising efforts and make this award as long as we have funds to do so.
FY 21-22.goal1: Our first priority is to increase our funding portfolio, with an emphasis on applying for grants in the Population Dynamics Branch (PDB) of NICHD. Expanding funding in the latter agency will increase our ability to be successful in being funding by a future center grant from NICHD.
FY 21-22.goal2: Our second main priority is to forge linkages with other units on campus that do not know about CSDA but could potentially benefit from alignments with population-based researchers and from whom CSDA associates could benefit. We are particularly interested in developing capacity for our research associates to engage in research that links climate change and disasters to the demographics that they are currently studying and that are CSDA’s themes – health, migration, and spatial inequalities. None of our CSDA associates are currently from the College of Emergency Preparedness, Homeland Security, and Cybersecurity (CEHC) or from the Department of Atmospheric and Environmental Sciences. However, the research that is conducted in both units is focused on disasters and climate change, which has implications for all of the main foci of CSDA.
FY 21-22.goal3: Our third priority is to explore ways to attract students, particularly underrepresented minorities, to engage in population-based research, enhance student experiences of those already engaged in population-based research, and ultimately, through the former endeavors, grow a workforce to assist CSDA associates.
FY 21-22.actions1:
"--Encourage CSDA Associates to put in proposals by educating them about the research priorities of PDB
--We have a grant review program to encourage our associates to apply for grants via PDB. This program will continue into next year."
FY 21-22.actions2: Host meetings to facilitate connections to researchers on campus outside of CSDA that work on climate change and disasters.
FY 21-22.actions3:
"We sought to hire work-study students via the federal work study program to work specifically on research with CSDA associates, many of whom are first-generation students and/or from underrepresented minority backgrounds.

We sought funding opportunities to assist in attracting these students to work at CSDA."
FY 21-22.metrics1: We assess the number of proposals submitted to NICHD PDB and the number of awards made.
FY 21-22.metrics2: "--number of meetings --number of attendees at meetings"
FY 21-22.metrics3:
"-- number of students working at CSDA
-- applications for funding opportunities"
FY 21-22.actionsImplemented1: We had fewer proposals submitted than we had desired.
FY 21-22.actionsImplemented2: Friedman and Lin have collaborated on two grants in this area.  Three of the four colloquia we had this year focused on climate change and health topics. We had researchers partcipate that were not CSDA associates.
FY 21-22.actionsImplemented3: We hired two work-study students to work with CSDA Director Friedman on amassing information about CSDA Associates publications in past year and over the past 3 years. One of the work-study students worked with Friedman on her research.
FY 21-22.noteworthyResults1:
We have three active awards:
1) Chatterji and Strully -- R03 -- ""Effects of Medicaid expansions on infant health among Native Americans"" -- 5/1/21 -- 4/30/22 -- $154,500
2) Strully and Appleton -- R21 -- via RAND -- ""Assessing individual, community, and financial factors in birth outcomes and associated health disparities"" -- 9/15/20 -- 8/31/21 -- $58,438
3) Markowitz and Chatterji -- R03 -- via NBER -- ""An exploratory study of the social and economic determinants of maternal morbidity in the US"" -- 8/1/20 -- 7/31/22 -- $100,000

In addition, we have another proposal that was revised and submitted again and is currently under review:
1) Ho and Chatterji -- R03 -- "Effect of losing hospital-based obstetric services on maternal health in rural communities."
FY 21-22.noteworthyResults2: Lin and Friedman have a grant with a fundable score from the EPA, and we are awaiting final approval (June/July). Our collaboration grew out of the CSDA event that took place in 2020-2021.
FY 21-22.noteworthyResults3: One of the work-study students, Sherlyn Mercado, was awarded a CURCE fellowship to participate virtually in the Population Association of America (PAA) meeting for her research with Friedman and colleagues. The student also presented the poster at the Undergraduate Research Expo at UAlbany that Friedman and colleagues had presented at the PAA meeting.
FY 21-22.changes1: A program officer recently gave a talk at a meeting of the Association of Population Centers (APC), of which we are a member. We will share the Zoom meeting with our CSDA Associates and try to identify barriers that prevent them from applying.
FY 21-22.changes2: We plan to continue forging linkages with ASRC and begin to forge linkages with CEHC. We will hold flash talk events among smaller groups of researchers to facilitate their ability to get to know each other's research and highlight emerging funding opportunities.
FY 21-22.changes3: CSDA will continue to work encourage its Research Associates to hire students to engage in their research via the federal work-study program or the G.R.E.A.T program.
FY 21-22.noofpartners: I provided this last year.  Can you please get it from my report last year?
FY 21-22.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch: Grow the data support staff at the university. We have Master's degrees in Biostatistics, Data Analytics, Econometrics, Information Science, and GIS among other fields. Yet, we have no infrastructure for researchers to get assistance with their data analysis, statistics, and mapping/spatial statistics. DMAC is limited. CSDA has a very limited GIS capacity, but this is something that can be grown, and we will explore this option in the upcoming year.
FY 21-22.bigChallenges: The university lacks a solid research infrastructure to offer PIs programming/data analytic support. If researchers have to obtain data, clean data, run analyses, there's little time left to write grants and publish papers. We need mid-level people to do these tasks and leave the big ideas and science generation to the faculty.
FY 21-22.resourceNeeds: We would value getting an administrative assistant and/or graduate student for CSDA. All we have as far as staff is a half-time GIS person. This hardly constitutes a sufficient staff to maintain/grow a research center that continues to bring significant visibility to UAlbany.
FY 21-22.strategicSuggestions: Build the research infrastructure core that I mentioned.  That is critical to not only CSDA but all researchers on campus.
FY 21-22.otherthoughts: The VPR's office should assist in forging linkages on campus between units. The Engaged Researchers model should be applied to other areas that align with the President's vision -- e.g., Climate Change, Disasters, and Minority Health Disparities; Minority Health Disparities in Maternal Health and Mortality.  This would link researchers on campus together and would facilitate their ability to apply for funding.

FY 22-23.mission: CSDA's mission is to facilitate and organize population research and education of the highest caliber. It seeks to accomplish this mission by creating a stimulating and cohesive intellectual environment conducive to the development of multidisciplinary population scholarship, particularly on the Center's signature themes of spatial inequalities and vulnerable populations.  Key areas of research include health and health disparities, immigration, risks to youth and adolescents, spatial inequalities and migration, American families, and social resources and vulnerabilities of the elderly.
FY 22-23.vision: Our vision is to increase our funding portfolio, forge linkages with other units on campus that don't know about CSDA, attract students from underrepresented minority groups to engage in population-based research, and conduct strategic planning to solidify our larger vision moving forward.
FY 22-23.annualBudget: At this point, we have no other sources of budget for our half-time employee, Jin-Wook Lee, who we share with the Lewis Mumford Center (AVAIL). We are working on finding other sources of funding for Mr. Lee.
FY 22-23.goal1: Our first priority is to increase our funding portfolio, with an emphasis on applying for grants in the Population Dynamics Branch (PDB) of NICHD.  Expanding funding in the latter agency will increase our ability to be successful in being funding by a future center grant from NICHD.
FY 22-23.goal2: Our second main goal is to continue to forge linkages with other units on campus that either do not know about CSDA or have started to know about CSDA. We are particularly interested in continuing to develop capacity for our research associates to engage in research that links climate change and disasters to the demographics that they are currently studying and that are CSDA’s themes – health, migration, and spatial inequalities. None of our CSDA associates are currently from the College of Emergency Preparedness, Homeland Security, and Cybersecurity (CEHC) or from the Department of Atmospheric and Environmental Sciences. However, the research that is conducted in both units is focused on disasters and climate change, which has implications for all of the main foci of CSDA. We would also like to forge linkages with the Department of Computer Science and College of Engineering.
FY 22-23.goal3: Our third priority is to explore ways to attract students, particularly underrepresented minorities, to engage in population-based research, enhance student experiences of those already engaged in population-based research, and ultimately, through the former endeavors, grow a workforce to assist CSDA associates.
FY 22-23.actions1: To achieve this goal, we will 1) have a colloquium series this year to showcase successful NICHD grantees from other universities and their research; 2)  organize meetings around each of our core themes -- 1) population health; 2) immigration and internal migration; and 3) spatial inequalities -- with our faculty associates working in those areas to identify opportunities for future collaboration as it fits with the Population Dynamics Branch of PDB.
FY 22-23.actions2: 1) Host meetings to facilitate connections between our CSDA associates and researchers on campus outside of CSDA that work on climate change and disasters and/or social networks/computing. 2) Invite key stakeholders like Chris Thorncroft and Eric Stern to be on our Advisory Board. 3) Continue to explore funding mechanisms to bring collaborations across these units. At a meeting I recently attended of the Association of Population Centers, we were informed that a working group at NICHD is discussing potential funding options linking climate change and health.
FY 22-23.actions3: To achieve this goal, we will 1) identify our associates who are working on research with undergraduates; 2) make CSDA activities more visible to undergraduates at UAlbany by encouraging their participation in our colloquium series and by holding virtual events surrounding Census 2020; 3) network with other departments who do not know about CSDA but whose students could be of great value to CSDA associates (e.g., data science, statistics, and information science); and 4) form a small group of CSDA associates that will collaborate to write a proposal for the National Science Foundation Research Experience for Undergraduates due in August 2021.
FY 22-23.metrics1: We will measure our success by gauging the increase in applications for funding to NICHD and other funding agencies.
FY 22-23.metrics2:
1) Number of meetings
2) Number of attendees at meetings
3) Number of collaborative publications
4) Number of collaborative grants
5) Number of new CSDA associates from ASRC/CEHC and other departments
FY 22-23.metrics3: Our success will be based upon our ability to attract undergraduate students to participate in our events; to involve more undergraduate and graduate students of color in the research of CSDA associates; and to apply for funding via the NSF REU mechanism.
FY 22-23.impactWorkplan1: We have no administrative support nor does Friedman get any course release time or summer salary for being Director of CSDA.  It's up to Friedman to accomplish everything, in addition to teaching two courses per semester (i.e., four courses per year) as well as complete her own research.  The only staff present in CSDA is a 50% support person who is a GIS specialist and not an administrative assistant.
FY 22-23.impactWorkplan2: We have no administrative support nor does Friedman get any course release time or summer salary for being Director of CSDA.  It's up to Friedman to accomplish everything, in addition to teaching two courses per semester (i.e., four courses per year) as well as complete her own research.  The only staff present in CSDA is a 50% support person who is a GIS specialist and not an administrative assistant.
FY 22-23.impactWorkplan3: We have no administrative support nor does Friedman get any course release time or summer salary for being Director of CSDA.  It's up to Friedman to accomplish everything, in addition to teaching two courses per semester (i.e., four courses per year) as well as complete her own research.  The only staff present in CSDA is a 50% support person who is a GIS specialist and not an administrative assistant.
FY 22-23.impactResearchExcellence1: This priority fits directly with the Strategic Plan’s goal, in the Research Excellence area, of increasing the ratio of faculty with research grants.
FY 22-23.impactResearchExcellence2: Forging collaborations across programs is one of the main priorities of the Strategic Plan in the area of Research Excellence.  Also, focusing on Climate Change, Emergency Preparedness, and Health and interdisciplinary research fits squarely within the Signature Research Strengths outlined by President Rodriguez in his Spring 2021 Presidential Address.
FY 22-23.impactResearchExcellence3: This priority fits well with at least four of the five pillars of the Strategic Plan – 1) to “empower faculty, staff and students to engage in innovative research” (Research Excellence); 2)  to promote the retention of students and to provide them with research experiences outside of the classroom (Student Success); 3) to retain underrepresented minority students and foster an inclusive learning environment (Diversity & Inclusion); and 4) “to facilitate productive and mutually beneficial synergies between UAlbany and regional and state partners” (Engagement & Service).

FY 21-22.mission: The RNA Epitranscriptomics and Proteomics Resources (REPR) was created by consolidating the RNA analysis and proteomics capabilities existing at the University at Albany. This specialized resource offers an extensive range of state-of-the-art mass spectrometry instrumentation and know-how. The mission is to capitalize on the extensive expertise in the analysis of RNA, RNA modifications, and proteins involved in RNA metabolism/regulation to benefit both internal and external investigators interested in these types of topics.
FY 21-22.vision: The resource supports also projects involving the analysis of a wide range of biomolecules, metabolites, and small synthetic molecules. In addition to providing full-service analysis, REPR welcomes the opportunity to enter full-fledged partnerships that may involve extensive consulting on experimental design, sample preparation and data interpretation, as well as whole project development and grant writing contributions. Please, contact us to inquire on how we can best help you.

FY 21-22.topAchievements1: 1. The operation of REPR was steady and preserved its ability to provide exceptional services to its users. We maintained, troubleshooted and repaired eight mass spectrometers including Bruker FT-ICR, Waters IMS-MS, Thermo Orbitrap Velos, Agilent 6120, Agilent QTOF 6530, Sciex 6500 QTRAP, Sciex QSTAR XL, and Waters TQ-S.
FY 21-22.topAchievements2: 2. New REPR capabilities includes cross-linking mass spectrometry for structural proteomics research and RNA modifications discovery using SIM on the Orbitrap system configured with an Acquity nanoflow UPLC.

Serviced 14 Investigators and their students from the University at Albany, Awarded  >191K in subcontracts, participated in 11 grant applications, new NIH NIGMS RO1 received outstanding score of (28, 16%), NIH NIEHS renewal grant scored outstanding (15, 1%), with both hopeful for funding by September 2022.

FY 21-22.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch: Mass spectrometry is a cutting edge technology that is a growth area for biomedical research.  This technology will continue to be a required approached for R1 Universities.  Epitranscriptomics detection is unique to a handful of labs in the world, and our continued expertise provides a unique resource to the Albany and NY community.
FY 21-22.bigChallenges: Acquiring new MS technologies, tools and training the next generation of users.
FY 21-22.resourceNeeds: New REPR Director is needed to ensure the continued success of the unit.  The current interim director has been doing the job for 3 years.
FY 21-22.strategicSuggestions: Recruit a new director from outsdie the University.

FY 21-22.mission: To provide ion beam irradiation and implantation education, training, and services to researchers from UAlbany, other academic insitutions, federal research agencies, and private industry to probe structure of materials, affect modification of structure by and impact of ion irradiation on their physical, chemical, and electronic properties.
FY 21-22.vision: The Ion Beam Laboratory (IBL) strives to remain one of the leading laboratory of its kind in the nation and offer a wide variety of irradiation, measurement, and analysis facilities and services to researchers. The IBL assists its users and partners in advancing the science and technology of biological, chemical, solid state, and electronic materials leading to the growth of new businesses in New York state and the country.
FY 21-22.topAchievements1: One of IBLs associates, Dr. Danielle Cherniak, an adjunct professor in the department of physics at UAlbany, submitted a proposal on "Decoding thermal and magmatic history of mafic and ultramafic rocks through systematic studies of cation diffusion in pyroxene" to the National Science Foundation and received $150,455 in grant. This project is wholly based on the use of IBL in her research. This grant represents the first IBL-based grant awarded directly to UAlbany personnel in over 10 years! The IBL continues to assist its users, especially at SUNY POLY, in securing extraural grants from federal and private sources. We hope to have more successes of this kind in coming years.
FY 21-22.topAchievements2: Students in the research group of Professor Harry Efstathiadis at SUNY POLY conducted a pilot study of ion migration in Li-ion batteries to be used in electric cars by BMW. Based on the success of the studies, he received a significant ($300+ K) multiyear grant from BMW.
FY 21-22.topAchievements3: We designed and started building auxiliary equipment the DARPA project of Dr. Mengbing (SUNY POLY). This has resulted in the project moving to phase 2 which will utilize a large amount of beam time at the IBL and likely to lead to the phase 3 which will be a larger scale production run and have significant impact on research outcomes.
FY 21-22.topAchievements4: The Ion Beam Laboratory has embarked on expansion of its student training program by teaming, for example, with Hudson Valley Community College’s (HVCC) Gene F. Haas Center for Advanced Manufacturing Skills (CAMS). Under this collaboration, HVCC students manufacture consumable components for the IBL. The components are then used in the IBL to maintain its two accelerators and multiple spectrometers. Through this program HVCC students gain valuable experience designing and building real-life components, and the IBL receives quality components to replace those that are nearing the end of their service. Review of the website and video below will be useful: https://www.albany.edu/news-center/news/2021-ion-beam-lab-50-years-materials-research https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G9e8VAkZlxE
FY 21-22.topAchievements5: Implanted Osmium onto a sample to simulate Solar wind effects for the Genesis project (NASA, JPL). Bill Lanford and Daniele Cherniak have also been working with Amy Jurewicz of Arizona State University to characterize diamond like carbon for the same project.
FY 21-22.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch: The IBL is looking into designing and constructing a low energy implanter for NASA, JPL to simulate Solar wind exposure. No other facility is known to have this capability.

otherAchievements.Achievement: The Extrion implanter was refitted with more modern hardware and electronics. It will now be able to service a larger number of researchers with improved control the implantation process.

FY 21-22.mission: The Center for Human Services Research is dedicated to developing empirically based knowledge to improve the design and delivery of services that address social issues and meet community needs. We conduct evaluation research and design information systems to inform policymakers and service providers across a broad spectrum of fields. The Center for Human Services Research values integrity in its research and is dedicated to providing timely, accurate, and non-biased information to guide best practice in the human services.
FY 21-22.vision: To be the leading university-based research center in the nation that provides leaders and practitioners with empirically based knowledge and technological innovations to create a better world.

Sponsored project funds
Small amount of funding from University for Data Management & Analytics Center

(2022) Patients’ Perspectives on Emergency Department COVID-19 Vaccination and Vaccination Messaging Through Randomized Vignettes. Public Health Reports, 13(4).

Research & Evaluation Within an Early Parenting Intervention Program: Ideas from Healthy Families New York (Gullick, M.M., & Kirkland, K.), The Boys’ and Girls’ Clubs Association of Hong Kong 2022 Symposium on Early Childhood Intervention (International), Hong Kong/Virtual.
FY 21-22.otherActivities: Creation of series of publically accessible Research Briefs summarizing results of Medicaid Redesign Team Supportive Housing Initiative evaluation. Participation in regular Partner Meetings with project external partners. Presentations at local and national practitioner conferences.
FY 21-22.topAchievements1: CHSR completed a series of 30 virtual focus groups as part of a needs assessment and gap analysis for the NYS Birth through 5 Preschool Development Grant (administered by the NYS Council on Children and Families). These focus groups targeted NYS parents with young children (ages 0-5) and asked about experiences with the early care and education systems. This pivot to virtual focus groups, paired with a significant time investment into new recruitment strategies and partnerships, resulted in a much larger (N=250) and more diverse participant pool than previous year’s in-person focus group efforts, and thus collected the experiences of more types of parents from around the state.
FY 21-22.topAchievements2: The Data Management and Analytics Center (DMAC), a part of CHSR, continued to provide individual technical assistance and data analytics support to UAlbany faculty, but also expanded its services to partner with the UAlbany libraries on the Data Management Plan Tool (DMPTool), and initiated a partnership with SUNY Downstate to provide hourly research support services (e.g., statistical consulting, survey instrument reviews, data visualization, etc.).
FY 21-22.topAchievements3: CHSR was selected as the vendor for the Perinatal and Infant Community Health Collaborative Data Management Information System by the NYS Department of Health, in response to a competitive RFP. This award includes over half a million dollars over five years to develop and maintain a web-based data collection and storage system.
FY 21-22.topAchievements4: All research staff completed training in trauma-informed evaluation, and participated in a group discussion about ways to translate these principles into concrete practices during research design, data collection, and analysis. This training ensures that all staff are up to date on best practices in evaluation and have a comprehensive understanding of trauma, its potential impacts on human services clients, and how to best protect participants while gathering high-quality data and answering each project’s key evaluation questions.
FY 21-22.topAchievements5: CHSR completed a self-study for the University at Albany evaluating the current standing of students from historically excluded groups within STEM majors by conducting focus groups and interviews with students and faculty, conducting a survey, and analyzing administrative data. This work has resulted in critical information for the University to use to better recruit and support students of color in the hard sciences, and is informing the University’s current application for additional funding under the HHMI Driving Change initiative.

otherAchievements.Achievement: CHSR received approval from the NYS Department of Health to release a suite of reports evaluating the Medicaid Redesign Team Supportive Housing Initiative, including two reports on the impact of these supportive housing programs on Medicaid spending and utilization, in comparison to changes for a comparison group. These reports have been made available on the CHSR website, LinkedIn page, Facebook page, and DMAC twitter account.

CHSR collaborated with attending faculty at the Albany Medical Center on a research project assessing ED patients’ COVID-19 vaccination status, perspectives, and hypothetical receptivity to ED-based vaccination, finding that EDs have appropriate patient populations to initiate COVID-19 vaccination programs as a supplement to community efforts. Further, simple opt-in approaches may offer the best messaging to reach vaccine-hesitant ED patients.

FY 21-22.mission: The mission of the Center for Functional Genomics is to develop expertise on new and developing genomic technologies that advance and improve the understanding of biology. As part of its mission, the CFG maintains core competencies in genomics, epitranscriptomics, epigenetics and bioinformatics.
FY 21-22.vision: The Center for Functional Genomics provides state-of-the-art services that enables scientists to conduct innovative research utilizing resources for which cost, operational investment, and expertise is most efficiently and effectively supported as a shared resource, fostering the growth of biotechnology at the University at Albany and throughout the Capital Region.

FY 21-22.topAchievements1: We have successfully implemented the launch of the NextSeq2000 sequencer. This enables our users to generate high quality DNA/RNA sequencing data at a more cost-efficient scale.
FY 21-22.topAchievements2: We have built workflow pipelines for new methodologies to enable single cell applications that allow our users to do cutting edge research
FY 21-22.topAchievements3: We have continued to build our customer base and provide assay services in Sanger sequencing, Next Gen sequencing, Microarrays and quantitative PCR. Our efforts in maintaining some of these aging instrumentation allow us to develop new methods using fragment analysis for detection of invasive species
FY 21-22.goal1: Development of new genomic methods for transcriptomics and epitranscriptomics to enable investigators at UAlbany and collaborating institutions to advance research.
FY 21-22.actions1: Build workflow pipelines for new methodologies to enable Chip-seq, ATAC-Seq, Cut-n-RunSeq and single cell applications
FY 21-22.metrics1: #Projects completed that enable investigators to complete these assays Publications with us as co-authors or acknowledgements
FY 21-22.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch:
1. Once we are moved to the main campus, we can partner with faculty research groups on main campus (LSRB/RNA Institute and ETEC) on various projects that would utilize our genomics services
2. Our current collaborations with SUNY Cobleskill and DEC could open new avenues for surveillence of invasive species
3. Our collaborations with HVCC and ABRF could allow us to partner in other mentoring opportunities funded by NSF
FY 21-22.bigChallenges:
1. Our instrumentation is aging and needs upgrading/replacement
2. Our current operational models are in need of revision:
(a) There is no budget for R&D efforts. This makes it more difficult to develop new methods
(b) CFG needs to be included in grant proposals that utilize our services.
(c) Currently it takes a lot of time and effort to track payments between RF/State to reconcile with our own records that are more up to date.
(d)Deficit funding does not allow us to forecast our future budgets effectively.

3. There is no marketing or advisory support for our services. While we have been doing a decent job, it would help to reconstitute a Scientific Advisory Board and a Faculty Advisory Board for guidance and direction
FY 21-22.resourceNeeds:
1. A liquid handling robot to automate routine tasks and improve efficiencies.
2. Scientific Advisory Board and a Faculty Advisory Board for guidance and direction
3. Inclusion with other units to better focus on University priorities
FY 21-22.strategicSuggestions:
1. Relocate to main campus to be better integrated with Life Science Initiatives
2. Look for synergies between various core facilities on campus to develop new methods. Currently each facility runs independently without strategic overlaps in vision/priorities.
FY 21-22.otherthoughts: Better marketing of our resources especially to outside entities that will build revenue

partners.Department: Department of Natural Sciences and Mathematics

FY 21-22.mission: Through fundamental and applied interdisciplinary research, the mission of the Atmospheric Sciences Research Center is to expand our understanding of the physical and chemical processes that govern the atmosphere-land-water system to improve the quality of life and economic well-being of citizens across New York State, the nation and the world.
FY 21-22.vision: To maintain and expand ASRC as a global leader in atmospheric and environmental sciences research and its application to the betterment of society, in an inclusive and collaborative environment that values integrity, diversity and the well-being of all.
FY 21-22.topAchievements1:
Center of Excellence promotes Renewable Energy and Grid Resiliency and is awarded $1M for FY 22/23.

The ASRC-led Center of Excellence in Weather and Climate Analytics continues to drive applied research in collaboration with industry. A major activity this past year has been the successful mobilization of support from NSF for an IUCRC planning grant to establish a consortium of industrial partners concerned with Renewable Energy and Grid Resiliency (Weather Innovation and Smart Energy and Resilience: WISER). This represents a significant and strategic collaboration with the University of Connecticut.

Also, in April we learned the good news that our COE was to be funded at the $1M level for 22/23. Significantly, this included $800K in the executive budget which provides some security for future years.

See: https://www.albany.edu/news-center/news/2022-plans-new-weather-innovation-smart-energy-and-resilience-center-draw-energy
FY 21-22.topAchievements2:
Center receives $1M endowment to support research in renewable energy and grid resiliency.

During this period ASRC received a $1M endowment to support research in Renewable Energy and Grid Resiliency. The fellowship will provide support for a doctoral fellow focused on interdisciplinary research aimed at enabling effective deployment of renewable energy on the electric grid using innovative insights from the atmospheric sciences and other fields. Research will focus on topics such as advanced resource assessment in a changing climate; large-scale integration of renewable energy on the grid; economic assessment of renewable energy deployments; renewable energy public policy and education; and energy infrastructure resiliency maximization.
FY 21-22.topAchievements3:
ASRC-led research to help reduce methane emissions in New York.

Dr. Jim Schwab is leading a new collaborative project to locate New York’s largest sources of methane emissions using ASRC’s mobile laboratory equipment to collect advanced air quality observations across the state. ASRC received $548,000 from the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority (NYSERDA) through its Environmental Research Program to support this effort.

See: https://www.albany.edu/news-center/news/2022-asrc-air-quality-researcher-leads-project-help-reduce-methane-emissions-new
FY 21-22.topAchievements4:
Collaboration with IBM Research.

A formal research partnership was announced between UAlbany and IBM Research to work on weather and climate impacts in NY State. Focus areas include harmful algal blooms, winter road weather, flooding, renewable energy and Numerical Weather Prediction.

See: https://www.albany.edu/news-center/news/2022-ualbany-ibm-announce-new-partnership-research-weather-and-climate-impacts
FY 21-22.topAchievements5:
Federal Advocacy Success.

Through working with our Federal Advocacy firm Clark Hill, we have achieved some notable successes for FY2022.

FY2022
(i) $900K of new money was achieved for the Profiler Test Bed Project, in the form of an earmark.
(ii) $3M in support of empowering emergency managers with tools derived from mesonet data was included in the form of appropriations language (target DHS S&T). ASRC is working with CEHC to mobilize the $3M.

This represents a significant return on investment. Clark Hill continues to advocate for Mesonet-related projects for FY2023 including promotion of research and infrastructure for renewable energy efforts including offshore wind.

FY 22-23.mission: Through fundamental and applied interdisciplinary research, the mission of the Atmospheric Sciences Research Center is to expand our understanding of the physical and chemical processes that govern the atmosphere-land-water system to improve the quality of life and economic well-being of citizens across New York State, the nation and the world.
FY 22-23.vision: To maintain and expand ASRC as a global leader in atmospheric and environmental sciences research and its application to the betterment of society, in an inclusive and collaborative environment that values integrity, diversity and the well-being of all.
FY 22-23.annualBudget: People: ASRC’s 14 faculty and 7 staff (including one full-time staff person at Whiteface Mountain) are supported by UAlbany. Over the past five years, ASRC’s payroll expenditures totaled $10,706,372 – an average of $2,141,274 per year. One full-time research facilitator and one part-time IT support person are supported by the VPR. Post-docs, research scientists, visiting scholars, graduate students, and undergraduate students are primarily paid from research grants; some are supported from start-up funds provided to SUNY2020 faculty. Most ASRC faculty are on 9-month academic year appointments and are paid summer salary from research grants or start-up funds. OTPS: ASRC’s operations, including operations at the UAlbany location and at Whiteface Mountain, are covered by IFR revenue recovered from sponsored programs. Over the past five years, ASRC’s OTPS expenditures at the Albany location have totaled $202,696, an average of $40,539 per year. Not counting annual telephone charges of almost $19,000 per year, OTPS expenses at ASRC average about $21,539 per year. The Whiteface location’s OTPS expenditures over five years total $77,606, an average of $15,521 per year. One faculty member had a legacy IFR account that covered some OTPS expenses such as Verizon Wireless. Strategic Investment: In the past, ASRC has received overhead recovery from the VPR to be used to grow research activity at ASRC. We have about $70,900 remaining in cash to spend on the state-side. On the RF side there is a legacy overhead recovery account primarily used in support of our RF p-card program as the initial source to pay the Bank of America bill monthly; expenses are then moved to the appropriate sponsored award through a reconciliation process. Events: ASRC has both UAlbany Foundation funds in the Ray Falconer Endowment and UAS (Auxiliary Services) funds to support lectures and colloquies.

data.Unit: Center for Elimination of Minority Health Disparities

FY 21-22.unit: Center for Elimination of Minority Health Disparities
FY 21-22.mission: The mission of the Center for the Elimination of Minority Health Disparities (CEMHD) is to contribute to the elimination of minority health disparities in the smaller cities and towns of New York State. CEMHD’s activities focus on three major interrelated areas, in the service of contributing to the elimination of minority health disparities: community engagement, fostering health disparities research, and supporting the development of new health disparities scholars.
FY 21-22.vision: The Center for the Elimination of Minority Health Disparities (CEMHD), is a collaborative effort focusing on minority health disparities in the smaller cities and towns of New York. Home to a 2016 NIMHD S21 Health Disparities Endowment Grant, a 2009 NIMHD P20 Exploratory Center of Excellence, and a 2004 NIMHD R24 EXPORT Center, CEMHD works toward eliminating health disparities by developing capacity in faculty at the University at Albany and partnering with community groups to identify their health concerns and the sources of disparities, and then plans, implements and tests strategies to alleviate them. CEMHD is a partnership among community groups, hospitals, state and county health departments, the State of New York and the University at Albany. CEMHD's focus on minorities and under-served populations in the smaller cities and towns of Upstate New York is premised upon the notion that health disparities found in these areas differ from those in the larger cities, and that the appropriate solutions will also differ. Since most of the research on minority health disparities, and the programs that have resulted from it, has focused on populations in large cities, relatively little is known about the distinct causes of poorer health among minorities in smaller cities. Therefore, another reason for our geographical emphasis is to fill in a gap in the research and to initiate and test the appropriate solutions.

FY 21-22.otherActivities:
President’s Award for Exemplary Public Engagement
Honorary Award for Distinguished Community Engagement

Christine T. Bozlak, Associate Professor, Health Policy, Management and Behavior, School of Public Health, and her partner, the Alliance of New York State YMCAs

Community Partners

    Kyle Stewart, executive director; Allison D'Antonio and Paige Hughes, former directors of healthy living; The Alliance of New York State YMCAs
FY 21-22.topAchievements1:
Doctoral training

a. Two new Health Disparities Training Fellows (HDTFs) were admitted for Fall 2021, chosen from among 46 applications, one to the Dept. of Latin American and Caribbean Studies and the other to the School of Public Health’s Dept. of Biomedical Sciences. Two students who joined the program in Fall 2017 successfully defended their dissertations (December/January), with degree conferral anticipated in spring/summer 2022. An additional defense is scheduled for August 2022. Three Fellows were admitted with support from the Hearst Foundations, one to the Dept. of Sociology, and two to Biology.
b. All of the S21-supported HDTFs (n=9) who began in fall of 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020, and 2021 have been retained through the current academic year. In addition, two fellows supported by Hearst Foundations that entered in 2020 have been retained, as have the three Hearst supported Fellows who entered in fall 2021.
FY 21-22.topAchievements2:
Hiring diverse faculty

a. A search is currently underway for a preeminent, nationally recognized scholar to anchor and lead the University’s efforts in health disparities research, training and outreach, with support from the Endowment for Community-Based Health Disparities Research and Training (S21 MD01069202), the SUNY Empire Innovation Professor (EIP) Program, and the University at Albany. An appointment is expected on or before June 30, 2022.
FY 21-22.topAchievements3:
Training faculty researchers, community members and leaders, HDTFs and their mentors in health disparities research by hosting events that expose participants to the latest developments in the field, and bring people together to share ideas, and gain expertise and support.
In April 2022, CEMHD hosted the fourth President’s forum entitled “Moving to Action in the Achievement of Health Equity” virtually (click here: www.albany.edu/healthdisparitiesforum). The keynote speech by Dr. Camara Phyllis Jones, a national expert on equity and health issues, “Achieving Health Equity: Naming Racism and Moving to Action” focused on the social and behavioral factors influencing racial differences on health outcomes and quality of life for African Americans. There were 231 registrations and 131 attendees, including Community partners, government officials, researchers, faculty, professional staff, postdoctoral associates, and students. This year’s Forum included, in addition to the keynote speaker and reaction panel, 3 concurrent panels, organized around the topics of Environmental Health Disparities, Maternal Health Disparities, and Health Communication, Digital Divide, and Messaging. Each panel featured 3 faculty researchers, as well as a community based practitioner.
FY 21-22.topAchievements4:
Strengthening community outreach, information dissemination, public engagement, and action related to health disparities research.

a. The CEMHD supports two local community task forces in Albany and Amsterdam, NY dedicated to community-researcher partnerships to address health disparities. Regular members include community leaders from these areas, mostly affiliated with governmental and non-governmental organizations dedicated to health and human services, and researchers from the University at Albany. Members of these task forces work together to identify causes and possible solutions for health disparities in the area, develop research projects to document these health disparities, and provide guidance and feedback on research projects in these communities. Both convene approximately once a month. The Albany Minority Health Task Force is mostly focused on the needs of African Americans and the poor in the city of Albany. The Amsterdam Minority Health Task Force focuses on the needs of migrants, non-English speakers (particularly Spanish speakers), mothers, and the elderly in the more rural region of Montgomery and Fulton counties of New York.
b. In 2020-2021, the Albany Minority Health Task Force, in collaboration with faculty from UAlbany and support from the University at Albany COVID-19 and MHD in NYS Engaged Researchers (ER) Group, designed and executed a survey to document the local impact of COVID-19 on communities of color. The report can be found in an open-access repository through the UAlbany Library’s Scholar’s Archive. In June 2021, CEMHD researchers presented survey results at the 2021 Summer Symposium - Differential Impacts of COVID-19 in NYS.
c. HDTFs participate in the community health task forces to develop the Fellows’ organizational and operational skills and qualifications as community engaged health disparities researcher, thus aiding in the acquisition of a professional position. Almost every Task Force meeting in 2021-2022 was attended by at least one Fellow. CEMHD continues to work on increasing outreach and communication to local and larger communities through our web presence within the UAlbany Website and through social media outlets. The website hosts both publications in health disparities for our Fellows and Associates, and any upcoming events that our HDTFs and Associates are involved in. Our quarterly CEMHD Newsletter/Bulletin is emailed to stakeholders and also available on our website. The Newsletter/Bulletin showcases achievements by Associates and Fellows, and highlights accomplishments of our Amsterdam and Albany Minority Health Task Forces. We also use social media, including Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter.
FY 21-22.topAchievements5:
Contributing to elevating the visibility of minority health disparities and health equity achievement as a central theme and signature strength of the University, such that training and research in this area will be ongoing for the foreseeable future, with S21 supported activities playing a central role.

The NIMHD S21 Endowment Program – particularly through its President’s Forum and Speakers Series – continues to raise the visibility of the University at Albany as a hub for health disparities research, training, and community outreach throughout Albany County, the greater Capital Region, the State of New York, and the northeastern United States. The endowment award and its invigoration of CEMHD drew the attention of the Governor of New York State in the spring of 2020, resulting in a request by the Governor to the University president to prepare a report on the differential impact of COVID-19 on communities of color.

The University at Albany’s academic and research community is now very aware of the NIMHD S21 Endowment award, especially the Health Disparities Research Training program. Academic departments across the University know about the funding opportunity for applicants to their doctoral programs, and applications to the program are steadily increasing.
FY 21-22.goal1: Provide continuing support to Fellows (recruitment been temporarily paused to ensure financial stability as the program transitions from combined University/endowment financial support to a self-sustaining status from the endowment; new admissions to the Fellowship program will resume with Fall 2023) in the form of stipends, tuition and fees, writing and statistics support, and conference travel support.
FY 21-22.goal2: Continue to support at least two community task forces to promote community engaged research and support community engagement.
FY 21-22.goal3: Promote health disparities research and collaboration among University at Albany researchers and their partners through the annual President’s Forum on Health Disparities and ongoing collaboration with the Engaged Researcher group of the newly forming Institute for the Achievement of Social and Health Equity.
FY 21-22.actions1:
Work with VPRED office and RF to transition all financial processes to RF.

Discuss recruitment plans with S21/CEMHD Executive Committee, President’s Office, Graduate School, and UAF.
FY 21-22.actions2:
Work with Task Force convenors and provide support from CEMHD in the form of Task Force Liaison to provide logistical support, convenors’ stipends, refreshments.

Facilitate interactions between University researchers and Task Forces.
FY 21-22.actions3:
Organize President’s Forum on Health Disparities, featuring a nationally recognized authority on health disparities, and interactively engaging faculty researchers and community members.

Collaborate with Engaged Researcher group on presentation of research talks by external experts on health disparities/health equity.
FY 21-22.actions4: Support the search for a preeminent, nationally recognized scholar to anchor and lead the University’s efforts in health disparities research, training and outreach. Support from the Endowment for Community-Based Health Disparities Research and Training (S21 MD01069202) is provided to complement support from the SUNY Empire Innovation Professor (EIP) Program, and the University at Albany. An appointment is expected on or before June 30, 2022.

FY 21-22.noteworthyResults3: Consider timing of President's Forum shifted to first half of spring semester, when there are fewer competing events on and off campus.
FY 21-22.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch:
1. Second $10M NIMHD S21 Health Disparities Endowment grant (2/3’s of all renewals have been approved). Eligibility criteria have been changed to include entities that have held COE awards, so UAlbany will be eligible.

2. NIMHD Centers of Excellence Program – Established by Minority Health and Health Disparities Research and Education Act of 2000 (Public Law 106-525), The Center of Excellence program plays a vital in supporting research in minority health and health disparities, promoting the training of a diverse research workforce, disseminating research findings, and fostering innovative collaborations and partnerships.  Funded Centers conduct transdisciplinary, multi-level research and provide research opportunities for post-doctoral fellows, junior faculty, and other early stage investigators to engage in this type of research.  The NIMHD COE is Congressionally Mandated and the NIMHD is expected to reissue the solicitation in the near future.
FY 21-22.bigChallenges: CEMHD is at capacity in administering the NIMHD S21 Health Disparities Endowment grant and Presidential Fellowship programD. In 2020, CEMHD received a $1,000,000 grant from the Hearst Foundation to support doctoral studies in health disparities, which allowed significant expansion of the program’s cohort. Together, the Hearst award and the S-21 endowment are now supporting a transdisciplinary doctoral fellowship program for 16 doctoral students from public health, social sciences, biological sciences, social welfare, and counseling psychology. Center staff are working to address administrative challenges accompanying this expansion while continuing to innovate to support the Fellows in their home departments, while ensuring that they receive the transdisciplinary training that is a signature strength of the fellowship program. As the endowment grows, and the Center is able to grow its research-related activities (e.g., pursuit of external research funding, speaker series, workshops for faculty to promote community enaged research, supporting pilot research projects), additional staff will be needed.
FY 21-22.strategicSuggestions: Funding of pilot projects that are specifically tied to the pursuit of external funding opportunities is an important strategy. Such activities should be complemented by support in grant seeking at NIH and NSF.

Center for Elimination of Minority Health Disparities

FY 22-23.unit: Center for Elimination of Minority Health Disparities
FY 22-23.mission: The mission of the Center for the Elimination of Minority Health Disparities (CEMHD) is to contribute to the elimination of minority health disparities in the smaller cities and towns of New York State. CEMHD’s activities focus on three major interrelated areas, in the service of contributing to the elimination of minority health disparities: community engagement, fostering health disparities research, and supporting the development of new health disparities scholars.
FY 22-23.vision: The Center for the Elimination of Minority Health Disparities (CEMHD), is a collaborative effort focusing on minority health disparities in the smaller cities and towns of New York. Home to a 2016 NIMHD S21 Health Disparities Endowment Grant, a 2009 NIMHD P20 Exploratory Center of Excellence, and a 2004 NIMHD R24 EXPORT Center, CEMHD works toward eliminating health disparities by developing capacity in faculty at the University at Albany and partnering with community groups to identify their health concerns and the sources of disparities, and then plans, implements and tests strategies to alleviate them. CEMHD is a partnership among community groups, hospitals, state and county health departments, the State of New York and the University at Albany. CEMHD's focus on minorities and under-served populations in the smaller cities and towns of Upstate New York is premised upon the notion that health disparities found in these areas differ from those in the larger cities, and that the appropriate solutions will also differ. Since most of the research on minority health disparities, and the programs that have resulted from it, has focused on populations in large cities, relatively little is known about the distinct causes of poorer health among minorities in smaller cities. Therefore, another reason for our geographical emphasis is to fill in a gap in the research and to initiate and test the appropriate solutions.

FY 22-23.goal1: Provide continuing support to Health Disparities Fellows in the form of stipends, tuition and fees, writing and statistics support, and conference travel support. Resume recruitment and admit 2 new Fellows to enter the program in Fall 2023.
FY 22-23.goal2: Continue to support at least two community task forces to promote community engaged research and support community engagement.
FY 22-23.goal3: Promote health disparities research and collaboration among University at Albany researchers and their partners through the annual President’s Forum on Health Disparities and ongoing collaboration with the Engaged Researcher group of the newly forming Institute for the Achievement of Social and Health Equity.
FY 22-23.goal4: Support submission of a renewal application for a $10M NIMHD S21 Health Disparities Endowment grant (FOA anticipated in FY 2022-2023).
FY 22-23.actions1:
Progress of Fellows in meeting home department requirements and Fellowship requirements (i.e., Experiential Learning Placements, Health Disparities Certificate Program, community task force participation).
Fellowship admissions
Fellows' satisfaction with academic support (writing and statistics)
FY 22-23.actions3: Organize President’s Forum on Health Disparities, featuring a nationally recognized authority on health disparities, and interactively engaging faculty researchers and community members.  Collaborate with Engaged Researcher group on presentation of research talks by external experts on health disparities/health equity.
FY 22-23.actions4:
Pre-proposal planning with support from VPRED office.
Coordination of proposal preparation with support from VPRED office.

FY 21-22.vision: We hope to bridge the gaps and barriers that exist in any academic institution so as to promote more interdisicplinary research, including grants, and training at the graduate levels in these areas of health and environment.

FY 21-22.topAchievements1: To promote interdisciplinary research:  We have received a grant from NIH for interdisciplinary research involving the Alaska Community Action on Toxics, the University of Arizona, Arizona State University, Emory University and UAlbany.
FY 21-22.topAchievements2: To promote community-based participatory research:  The above grant as well as an existing one are both focused on Alaska Native communities and health.  In addition Institute staff are involved in community health issues in the Albany South End.  Dr. Carpenter has been involved in speaking on issues related to the hazards coming from the Dunn Landfill in Renselaer, the Norlite facility in Colonie, the LaFarge cement plant south of Albany.
FY 21-22.topAchievements3: We have expanded our collaborative research and training activities in  South America, especially in Peru and Brazil where we have active collaboration and where Dr. Feingold has received an NIH grant from the Fogarty Foundation for her work in Peru.
FY 21-22.topAchievements4: We have an extraordinary group of doctoral students coming from many different countries, including Mongolia, Japan, Nigeria, Ghana, Sierra Leone, Bangledesh, India and Trinidad.  Five will graduate this spring.
FY 21-22.goal1: To promote interedisciplinary research and training
FY 21-22.goal3: To be research productive
FY 21-22.goal4: To promote intereactional activities with the World Health Organization and Collaborating Centres from other countries.
FY 21-22.actions1: Institute staff have served on dissertation committees in the Departments of Geography and English
FY 21-22.actions3: Our record of publications speaks for itself.  We have had at least 22 publications in peer-reviewed journals, and this is almost certainly an undercount.
FY 21-22.actions4: Last year we publication a major review on E-waste in Africa at the request of the WHO and we are currently working on a review on endocrine disruptive chemicals at their request.
FY 21-22.metrics1: We have added members to the Institute from the Departments of Philosophy, English and Geography and Planning.
FY 21-22.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch: Our World Health Organization Collaborating Centre is an extraordinary opportunity for the Insitute and for UAlbany.  It already has made a mark for international activity, and has the potential to do more in the future.
FY 21-22.bigChallenges: Lack of funding in a major problem, especially for international students.  Research funding is also limited but we have been quite successful there.

FY 21-22.mission: Transforming public services through innovations in management, policy, and technology.
FY 21-22.vision:
The Center for Technology in Government (CTG UAlbany) was established in 1993 to pursue new ways to use technology to address practical problems of information management and service delivery in government. It soon developed into an internationally-recognized research center within the University at Albany whose mission is to foster public sector innovation, enhance capability, generate public value, and support good governance. To achieve this mission, CTG UAlbany pursues the following strategic actions:

• To engage in innovative academic and applied research on complex societal challenges
• To become global leaders in digital government research and public sector digital transformation
• To develop and teach innovative courses that emphasize real-life applications of technology, management, policy, and data in the public sector
• To enable students to learn about societal challenges and apply technologies and policies in the context of specific projects
• To engage diverse professional communities in the transformation of public services

CTG UAlbany's competitive advantage:

• Unique combination of disciplines (public administration and public management, computer science, information systems, data science, business, international relations)
• Highly skilled academic and professional staff, who help bridge the gap between academia and practice by addressing public problems that are academically significant and practically relevant
• Network orchestrator, locally (government organizations, diverse stakeholders) and internationally (leader of multiple research networks)
• Co-creation approach in projects with government organizations that enable their engagement in creative problem-solving processes and the implementation of innovative and customized digital transformation solutions to complex problems
• “Center for Technology in Government” as a worldwide recognized “brand” developed and consolidated during the last 30 years
• Key location, close to decision-makers and international hubs
FY 21-22.annualBudget: CTG’s revenue stream consists of research grants and awards, corporate sponsored projects, and research agreements supported through the Research Foundation, as well as various University at Albany state and municipal MOUs and contract projects. This year, CTG will realize $429,245 in IFR revenue from seven RF projects and $265,182 from four state-side MOUs and contracts. Due to an overpayment on our Water Quality project by the sponsor, $115,255 of these funds were returned to the DEC. In addition, $68,294 in At-Risk Funding was returned by the budget office to our IFR account. Finally, total state overhead paid on these awards was $64,927. Taking all these factors into account, our net revenue for CTG FY 2021-2022 was $582,539. The remaining revenue helped to support annual operating expenses of $435,025. The expense categories included phones, technical equipment and software, postage, graduate students, temp service and term positions, supplies, service contracts, online and in-person training and conferences, non-project supported travel, state project-related expenses, and any other non-PSR expense needed to operate CTG. This figure also includes fringe for all non-student categories. CTG does not receive an annual OTPS allocation from the Division of Research, instead it revenue generates on its own to support CTG’s OTPS budget. CTG also received an allocation from Rock College to the PSR account in the amount of $18,000. This was used to cover temp salary expenses on our 900309 IFR account. CTG’s PSR state allocation of $680,857supported 6.34 FTEs. This was reduced by $176,318 from last year’s state allocation of $857,175 and 8 FTEs in order to help support the state-side budget deficit. Due to these reductions in state supported PSR, this year CTG needed to use IFR funds to support 2 research-related positions in order to continue the work needed on various research awards, including a researcher in digital government and a program associate. CTG continues to be very strategic with our business development goals and is committed to seeking out new funding opportunities and partnerships. This year, CTG was awarded a total of $923,419 through new State and RF awards. New State MOUs and contract awards included The NYS Board of Elections Futures (Phase II) award for $349,945 and the NYS Board of Elections Local Government Risk Remediation (Part 2) award for $39,000. Total new state awards equaled $388,945. New awards through the Research Foundation included a 3-year Message Design Dashboard: Development of a Standardized Messaging Tool through FEMA at $327,012 for year 1. Also, the City of Schenectady awarded the project, Enabling the State-Wide Rollout of the Share Regional Information Resource in the amount of $189,462. The NYS Association of Counties awarded CTG $16,000 to develop a Cyber Primer for local IT leaders. In addition, we received a gift in kind from NVIDIA to provide equipment and training for the TAF project already underway and is valued at approximately $2,000. Total New RF awards equaled $923,419. In addition, CTG has two proposals pending including the NSF Large-scale CoPe: Bridging Data to Action - Using Data and AI to Develop Equitable Outcomes While Augmenting Resilience to Climate Hazards in Coastal Communities for $864,923. Also submitted was a proposal to NSF for the Civic Innovation Challenge 2022 Planning Grant in coordination with the City of Schenectady for $50,000. Total potential new revenue awarded in the coming fiscal year totals $914,923. Residual funds not utilized in the next fiscal year will be used in the coming years to help continue support for the two temporary research IFR funded positions mentioned above, including our Researcher in Digital Government, as well as our Program Associate.
FY 21-22.additionalAmount2: $265,182 (before refund of overpayment from DEC & return of at-risk holding as noted above.)
